He completed Airborne and Glider Training during this assignment. Additional overseas tours included Korea, Germany, Iran, and Vietnam. As the Battalion Sergeant Major of the 2d Battalion, 327th Infantry Regiment, 101st Airborne Division in Vietnam, and a highly trained Ranger, his leadership skills became evident while accompanying a platoon search and destroy mission. He received the Bronze Star Medal for Valor which reads "while accompanying a platoon on search and destroy mission, the platoon was soon pinned down. Ranger Bacerra detecting the sniper's probable location, without hesitation rounded the platoon's right flank drawing rapid fire and moved quickly to a position to the rear of the sniper's location. When the sniper attempted to withdraw, Ranger Bacerra engaged and killed him in an individual firefight." Ranger Bacerra's disregard for his own personal safety was an inspiration to the members of the platoon. RGR Bacerra participated in every combat assault the battalion conducted during his assignment. He demonstrated physical and mental toughness during long periods in the field while accompanying teams on Long Range Reconnaissance and combat patrols. One night, RGR Bacerra informed his Battalion Commander at 2300 hours that he was making the midnight insertion with the HAWK Team. His Commander replied, "Sergeant Major, you're going to get your ass killed!" To which RGR Bacerra replied "Yes Sir," saluted and made the insertion. RGR Bacerra is the epitome of a Ranger Noncommissioned Officer and was a role model of the Ranger Noncommissioned Officer Gen Abrams envisioned when creating the modern day Ranger Battalions.

Bachmann enlisted in 1976 as an Infantryman, assigned to B Co1/75 Ranger from 1977-80, serving as a Squad Leader, as a Corporal (E-4). In 1978, he graduated from Ranger School, and was an Honor Graduate from the Primary NCO course (PNCO). In 1980, he trained on SPOPs after the Iran crisis. From 1981-84, Bachmann served with 2/75 Ranger, as a SGT E-5. He was promoted to Staff SGT, served as Weapons Squad Leader, Platoon SGT, and Platoon Leader in B Co. He was the Primary Jumpmaster for one of the five aircraft for the Combat Jump into Grenada and also served as the Pathfinder at Pointe Salinas for the Medical Student Rescue. He was selected as the TOC II jeep driver. He was a Member/Instructor of the battalion's Static Line Jumpmaster MTT program. He planned and coordinated the battalion's Airlift Missions in support of Reforger in Germany 1984. In 1984, Bachmann was selected as one of the Original Members of Team "Alpha", 75th Ranger Reconnaissance Detachment, serving from 1984–86 as the Assistant Team Leader, promoted to SGT First Class E-7, he assumed command as Team Leader of Team Alpha. From 1986-91, Bachmann served at Camp Darby, Fort Benning, GA as a Senior RI and also on the Instructor Certification Board for all new Ranger Cadre. Bachmann was selected multiple times each year as Instructor of the Cycle. While with 4th RTB, Bachmann served for 3 years as a member of the Post Skydiving Exhibition Team "The Silver Wings", logging over 900 jumps. From 1991-93, he served as the 7th Infantry Division's (L) Long Range Surveillance Detachment First SGT, serving as the unit Training Lead, the first divisional unit to receive the 7th Divisional Commanders Gold and Silver streamers for physical fitness and marksmanship excellence, two years in a row. He developed and implemented the Special Patrol Infiltration/Exfiltration System (SPIES) that had never been used in the division. He was the Primary Airborne and Small Unit Instructor for Forces United in Paraguay in 1992. From 1993-97, Bachmann took his Ranger Leadership to serve as the Senior Enlisted Advisor for ROTC at the U of WI-Stevens Point, as the Primary Recruiter/Trainer/Coach for the Ranger Challenge team, with teams going from last to third place. Bachmann retired after 20 years of service.

Ambassador and Lieutenant General Dell L. Dailey (Ret) is inducted into the U.S. Army Ranger Hall of Fame for 42 years of service as a Ranger, soldier, combat leader, decades of Special Operations, and distinguished civilian service as a Warrior-Statesman at the our Nation's highest levels. His Army career culminated as the Director of the Center for Special Operations, USSOCOM's military hub for counterterrorism, assuming synchronization responsibility for worldwide planning, intelligence and operations of U.S. Special Operations Forces (SOF). A 1971 West Point graduate, he was commissioned in the infantry and served in an outstanding manner in progressively demanding troop assignments in conventional and SOF units to include Ranger, Infantry, Air Assault, Airborne, Aviation and Armored Cavalry. He had multiple SOF assignments with the 75th Ranger Regiment and the 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment. He commanded two infantry companies, two aviation companies, two aviation battalions, and the 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment (Abn). He led from the front, always caring for his soldiers. LTG Dailey is a Master Parachutist with 120 jumps and a Master Army Aviator with 2400 flying hours. He distinguished himself in selected classified missions, Operations Desert Shield and Desert Storm. As Commander, Joint Special Operations Task Force (JSOTF), he executed sensitive, complex, early entry missions in both Operation Enduring Freedom and Iraqi Freedom and was considered the unsung hero as his assigned forces executed the most difficult missions in Army history. In 2007, Ambassador Dailey was selected by Secretary Rice, confirmed by the US Senate, and appointed by President George W. Bush as the Ambassador at Large for Counterterrorism, Department of State. Here he integrated joint military and interagency operations with international diplomacy. Today, in addition to being a successful Defense and Aerospace small businessman, he gives back by mentoring future SOF, State Department and prospective defense flag officers as national security leaders. LTG Dell Dailey's remarkable career of military leadership "On Point" and his visionary public service as a superb Warrior-Statesman epitomizes the time-honored Ranger Motto - "Ranger's Lead the Way!"

Ranger Fowler is a battle hardened Ranger combat veteran. Ranger Fowler was recruited by the 74th Infantry Detachment Long Range Reconnaissance Patrol to serve with the detachment conducting Long Range Reconnaissance for the 173d Airborne Brigade in Vietnam, re-designated as N Company (RANGER) 75th Infantry 1 February 1969. Ranger Fowler twice earned the Bronze Star for VALOR for complete disregard for his own personal safety when he exposed himself to intense enemy small arms fire and effectively engaged the enemy, thereby eliminating the enemy threat allowing successful completion of the Ranger Mission. After returning from Vietnam Ranger Fowler was assigned as a Ranger Instructor. His tough realistic demanding standards ensured his Ranger Students were prepared to assume their role as Ranger Leaders throughout the Army. Ranger Fowler was personally selected to serve as an original First Sergeant for B Company, 3d Ranger Battalion when it activated on 3 October 1984. He was instrumental in the development of Squad through Battalion Standard Operating Procedures and Battle Drills that enabled the battalion to be certified as trained and prepared to assume its role as a total combat fighting force. He was promoted to CSM and selected to lead as the Commandant of the Henry Caro Noncommissioned Officer Academy. He was instrumental in the development of the Squad Leader (Basic Noncommissioned Officer) and Platoon Sergeant (Advanced Noncommissioned Officer) Program of Instruction. Senior post leadership selected CSM Fowler to be the Infantry School CSM responsible as the senior enlisted advisor for all Infantry matters and provided input on doctrine, training, new weapons, equipment and safety for the Infantry Force. Ranger Fowler is a proven Ranger Leader who "Readily displayed the intestinal fortitude required to fight on to the Ranger Objective and complete the mission" as reflected by his eagerness to accept and specifically selected for demanding assignments. Ranger Fowler's passion and influence on the Army and the Ranger community remains as a standard for other to follow.

Command Sergeant Major Jeffrey L. Greer, United States Army, retired, is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his outstanding accomplishments, leadership, and service to the 75th Ranger Regiment, the Ranger Department, and the US Army over a career spanning 33 years. CSM Greer epitomizes the US Army paratrooper, having spent over 22 of those years on airborne status with the 82nd Airborne Division, 75th Ranger Regiment, the Ranger Training Brigade, and the 1-508th Airborne Battalion Combat Team. CSM Greer served as a platoon sergeant in the airborne assault into Panama with 2nd Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment during Operation JUST CAUSE, displaying the intestinal fortitude required to lead Rangers in combat. The quality of CSM Greer's leadership and experience qualified him to be selected as a command sergeant major at the Battalion and Brigade level as well as the US Corps of Cadets at West Point and the Military District of Washington. CSM Greer continues to make a contribution to the Nation's defense as the operations lead in the Logistics Directorate of the Terminal High Altitude Area Defense system project office in the Missile Defense Agency.

Colonel Guy served in three Ranger assignments, including one in combat, totaling almost 5 years with Ranger units and Ranger training organizations. Upon redeployment from Vietnam in 1967, Colonel Guy was assigned to the Ranger Training Command at Fort Benning as an instructor in the Patrolling Committee. As an instructor he taught patrolling techniques, night operations, map reading, and small unit tactics to Infantry School students during field tactical training. During this time, he designed and implemented the command's Jungle Firing Course, designed to use a new innovation called "quick kill" firing techniques in a combat environment simulating that of Vietnam. Among his duties while serving as the Assistant Operations Officer, Patrolling Committee was the responsibility for briefing all visitors and VIPs about the U. S. Army Ranger School and the extensive responsibilities of the Ranger Training Command. In July 1969, Colonel Guy assumed command of L Company (Ranger), 75th Infantry, 101st Airborne Division (Airmobile) in Vietnam. As the Company Commander during 1969 and 1970, Colonel Guy was responsible for preparing, inserting, extracting, and supporting four to six man Ranger teams conducting continuous long-range reconnaissance missions deep in enemy territory, often in the vicinity of the Laotian border and the former Khe Sahn Marine Corps base. On 31 March 1970, Colonel Guy led a classic company-sized raid operation into the NVA-occupied A Shau Valley to destroy North Vietnamese roads and bridges used by NVA truck convoys. In January 1978, Colonel Guy was assigned as Executive Officer of the 1st Battalion (Ranger), 75th Infantry, at Fort Stewart Georgia where he supervised staff preparation and execution of numerous battalion deployments and readiness exercises during the battalion's transition from a tactical combat unit to a special operations force. He worked closely with Special Force's "Blue Light" and other new special operations force units and was the briefing officer for Vice President Walter Mondale, CIA Director Admiral Stansfield Turner and numerous other dignitaries during special operations demonstrations in the spring of 1979. Colonel Guy served with distinction in three different Ranger assignments and has contributed to the Ranger legacy that exists today.

LTG John M. Le Moyne is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame in recognition of his loyalty and commitment to the U.S. Army and the nation during his distinguished 40-year career as a Ranger qualified leader. LTG Le Moyne enlisted in the U.S. Army in 1964 and while a Special Forces Sergeant with 11TH Special Forces Group (Airborne), 1st Special Forces, he was discharged to complete Army ROTC. After being commissioned in January 1968 he was assigned to the 82d Airborne Div, Ft. Bragg, NC. In 1969 he was assigned as an Advisor with the 6th Vietnamese Airborne Battalion and later as Commander, A Co., 4th Bn, 9th Inf, 25th Inf Div, RVN. Upon return from Vietnam he was assigned as an Instructor at the U.S. Army Ranger School, Eglin AFB, FL. LTG Le Moyne held every infantry leadership position from Platoon Leader through Assistant Division Commander and in 1999 became the Commanding General, U.S. Army Infantry Center and Commandant, U.S. Army Infantry School, Ft. Benning, GA. Previously he commanded 1st Bde, 24th Inf Div (Mech), in Operations Desert Shield/Storm and the 2nd Bn, 30th Inf, 3rd Inf Div, USAREUR. Other principle assignments included Chief of Staff, USAREUR and Seventh Army; Chief of Staff and G3, 24th Inf Div (Mech) Ft. Stewart, GA; Plans/Policy Officer, Mid-East, J-5, JSOC, Ft. Bragg, NC; S-3, 2nd Bn (Ranger), 75th Inf, Ft. Lewis, WA; and Action Officer, OPM-SANG, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. After the September 11, 2001 attack on the Pentagon, LTG Le Moyne served as Deputy Chief of Staff for Personnel, U.S. Army, Washington, DC until his retirement on December 31, 2003. LTG Le Moyne is a graduate of the British Royal College of Defense Studies; the Army War College and the Marine Corps Command and Staff College. His numerous awards include the Defense Distinguished Service Medal; Distinguished Service Medal (OLC); Legion of Merit (2OLC) Bronze Star Medal with "V" Device (5OLC); Purple Heart; Combat Infantryman Badge; Expert Infantryman Badge; Master Parachutist Badge; Pathfinder Badge; Ranger Tab; and Special Forces Tab. LTG Le Moyne set the example as a warrior, role model, trainer, mentor, and professional soldier - a "Soldier's Soldier" who lived the tenets of the Ranger Creed.

BG Herbert J. Lloyd is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his selfless commitment to the U.S. Army and the nation as he "led the way" during his distinguished 35-year career as a Ranger qualified leader. He enlisted in the Army in 1955 serving as a Rifleman through Platoon Sergeant. In 1962 he volunteered to train and advise Army of the Republic of Vietnam (ARVN) Rangers in combat operations and during the same tour extended to serve as an adviser with the Vietnamese Airborne Division. As a Sergeant First Class he graduated from Infantry OCS in August 1964. BG Lloyd deployed with the 82nd Airborne Division to the Dominican Republic in 1965 where as a 2LT he commanded a company in combat. He returned to Vietnam in 1966 through 1968 as an advisor to the 6th Vietnamese Airborne Battalion and returned again to Vietnam in 1972 as one of three officers individually selected by the Chief of Staff of the Army to develop "lessons-learned." After Vietnam, Lloyd served in numerous key command and staff assignments including: G3 Training Officer in the 82nd Airborne Division, Fort Bragg, NC; Chief of Tower Committee and Chief of Operations in the Airborne Department, USAIS, Fort Benning, GA. He served on the Staff and Faculty of the United States Military Academy as a Tactical Officer; and as Brigade Executive Officer, 8th Infantry Division, Germany; Commander, 3rd Battalion, 11th Infantry, Deputy Chief of Staff and Commander, 2nd Brigade, 5th Infantry Division, Fort Polk, LA; Chief of Staff, 10th Mountain Division, Fort Drum, NY; and prior to retirement, as Assistant Division Commander, 2nd Infantry Division, Republic of Korea. BG Lloyd's awards and decorations include the Silver Star (OLC); Soldier's Medal; Bronze Star Medal w/ V device (5OLC); Purple Heart (OLC) and numerous others. Immediately after retirement, and for the past 18 years, BG Lloyd has continued serving by holding a series of sensitive and still ongoing key defense-related civilian assignments in Africa, Southwest Asia and the Middle East. He has been a leader, mentor, trainer and role model to all officers, non-commissioned officers and civilians with whom he has served. His deeds have resulted in his well-deserved and recognized reputation; his life has been the exemplar of the Ranger Creed.

RGR Rollins is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame in recognition of his heroism in combat, outstanding accomplishments, and strong leadership abilities. He began his distinguished military career in July 1965. He completed Basic Airborne Training and was assigned to the 101st Airborne Division, Fort Campbell, Kentucky. He served 10 months in Vietnam with the 2d Battalion, 502d Infantry, 101st Airborne Division, and participated in Operation Attleboro and Operation Hawthorne with the reconnaissance platoon. He was awarded his first Purple Heart during this assignment. He then extended his tour and joined the Military Assistance Command Vietnam Studies and Observations Group for an additional 11 months. He attended the Luc Long Dac Biet (Republic of Vietnam Special Forces Course) and The RVN Basic Airborne Course conducted by US Special Forces for the RVN Special Forces. While assigned to 1st Field Force, 20th Infantry Airborne Long Range Patrol he participated in operation "Shining Brass / Prairie Fire" in Laos, "Daniel Boone" in Cambodia, "Muscle Shoals (Igloo White)," "Spear;" "Dawes;" "Buckner;" and "March." He was awarded his second Purple Heart for wounds received in combat actions in Laos in September 1968 and was medically evacuated from Vietnam and subsequently medically retired. Throughout his career, SSG(R) Rollins embodied the Ranger Creed and displayed the intestinal fortitude required to fight on to the objective and complete the mission.

Colonel (Ret.) Robert L. Tonsetic is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his heroic actions and distinguished service in combat in both Vietnamese Ranger and Airborne Battalions and US Army Light Infantry Units. Ranger Tonsetic served two combat tours in Vietnam the first as C Company Commander, 4th Battalion, 12th Infantry, 199th Infantry Brigade (SEP). On the first night of the 1968 Tet Offensive, as the C Company commander Ranger Tonsetic led a small task force of two understrength rifle platoons and an armored cavalry platoon in a night assault to intercept an enemy battalion of the 275th Viet Cong Regiment that was moving into position to attack the U.S. Long Binh Base complex. When the enemy attacked his platoons with heavy machine guns and 60mm mortars, Ranger Tonsetic led an assault on the enemy positions. After personally destroying an enemy heavy machine gun and mortars with grenades, he exposed himself to small arms fire and rocket shrapnel to locate and bring firepower on additional hostile positions forcing the enemy to withdrew to a defensive position along a ridge line. After evacuating his casualties, Ranger Tonsetic led a dawn attack on the entrenched enemy force. After five hours of heavy fighting, reinforcements arrived, and Ranger Tonsetic launched a coordinated ground and air attack against the enemy battalion which resulted in more than 200 enemy KIA and rendered the enemy battalion combat ineffective for the duration of the TET offensive. During his second combat tour, Ranger Tonsetic served as senior advisor to the 44th Vietnamese Ranger Battalion where he received a Bronze Star for valor for his heroic actions during an attack on an enemy mountain stronghold. Upon his retirement he was awarded the Defense Superior Service Medal.

General John Abizaid is inducted into the Ranger Hall of fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. He has been the absolute role model of a brilliant tactical leader; the consummated soldier statesman; and the definition of the authentic, genuine senior leader. He perpetuated the Ranger spirit in every position during his illustrious 34 years of service. He is a combat veteran of Grenada, Northern Iraq, Haiti, Bosnia Herzegovina, Kosovo, Afghanistan, and Iraq. He commanded at every level from company to Combatant Command. The culmination his distinguished career was as the Commander, United States Central Command. As Commander of Central Command, he led simultaneous international coalitions that operated in Iraq, Afghanistan, the Horn of Africa, and the Persian Gulf. Ranger Abizid's lasting impact on our Armed Forces and our allies was nurtured during his company grade years in two Ranger Battalions. He was hand-picked among thousands of lieutenants to serve in the newly activated 2nd Ranger Battalion in 1974. He served as a platoon leader, company executive officer and Headquarters Company Commander, greatly contributing to the Battalion passing its first grueling Army Readiness Evaluation Test and being declared combat ready in December 1975. As the Alpha company commander in the 1st Ranger Battalion, his unit was the lead element to parachute onto the island of Grenada in October 1983 and clear the runway at Salinas airport and seize the American Medical School where American medical students were believed to be in danger. This was the first combat operation in the history of the modern Ranger Battalions. The company found itself under heavy enemy fire and under Ranger Abizaid's courageous leadership, made an unplanned assault on the high ground north of the runway. His unit accomplished all its objectives and greatly contributed to the 1st Ranger Battalion earning the Valorous Unit Award in Grenada. As a Brigade, Divisional and CENTCOM Deputy and CENTCOM Commander, Ranger Abizaid worked closely with Special Operations leaders to ensure that Ranger units were used to their full potential in both counterinsurgency and counterterrorism roles. Ranger Abizaid's induction into the Ranger Hall of Fame serves as a lasting recognition of his lifetime commitment in the service of our nation and the free world.

LTG Steven L. Arnold is inducted in the Ranger Hall of Fame for his valorous actions and commitment during his distinguished 35 year career as a Ranger leader. He served two tours of duty in Vietnam; first in 1967 as the Recondo Force Leader in the 2nd Battalion, 502nd Airborne Infantry Regiment, 101st Airborne Division. In June 1967, he exposed himself to murderous enemy automatic weapons fire to rescue a wounded man and earned a Silver Star Medal. In August 1967, while commanding Company A, 2nd Battalion, 502nd Airborne Infantry Regiment, 101st Airborne Division, CPT Arnold was directing a search and destroy mission with a platoon size force in contact with a North Vietnamese reinforced company. On initial contact, one of his men was wounded, and CPT Arnold immediately called for a MEDEVAC helicopter. Approaching the landing zone, the helicopter came under intense automatic weapons fire downing the helicopter. CPT Arnold exposed himself to enemy fire to secure the helicopter and treat the wounded. That evening, his unit came under extremely heavy automatic and mortar fire. CPT Arnold received shrapnel fragments in the face and eyes. Despite his wounds, he continued to command his unit throughout the night and refused evacuation until ordered to do so. For his outstanding display of gallantry in action and his intense devotion to duty, CPT Arnold earned a second Silver Star Medal and two Purple Heart Medals. While commanding the 2nd Brigade, 82nd Airborne Division, COL Arnold was selected for promotion to brigadier general. Later he moved to serve as assistant division commander for operations, 2nd Infantry Division in Korea. In 1990, with the invasion of Kuwait by Saddam Hussein, BG Arnold commanded the 10th Mountain Division and served in Somalia with Operation Restore Hope. Arnold was promoted to LTG and commanded Third Army and ARCENT until his retirement in 1997. After retirement, LTG (R) Arnold became the senior project manager for KBR in in Camp Victory, Iraq supporting troops in eight countries with engineer, logistics, and life services.

First Lieutenant George Kenton Sisler is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for conspicuous gallantry and intrepidity at the risk of his life and above and beyond the call of duty. On February 7, 1967, First Lieutenant Sisler was the platoon leader/adviser to a Special United States/Vietnam exploitation force. While on patrol deep within enemy dominated territory, First Lieutenant Sisler's platoon was attacked from three sides by a company-sized enemy force. First Lieutenant Sisler quickly rallied his men, deployed them to a better defensive position, called for air strikes, and moved among his men to encourage and direct their efforts. Learning that two men had been wounded and were unable to pull back to the perimeter, First Lieutenant Sisler charged from the position through intense enemy fire to assist them. He reached the men and began carrying one of them back to the perimeter, He came under more intensive weapons fire by the enemy. Laying down his wounded comrade, he killed three onrushing enemy soldiers by firing his rifle and silenced the enemy machine gun with a grenade. As he returned the wounded man to the perimeter, the left flank of the position came under extremely heavy attack by the superior enemy force and several additional men of his platoon were quickly wounded. Realizing the need for instant action to prevent his position from being overrun, First Lieutenant Sisler picked up some grenades and charged single-handedly into the enemy onslaught, firing his weapon and throwing grenades. This singularly heroic action broke up the vicious assault and forced the enemy to begin withdrawing. During the final phase of the battle, First Lieutenant Sisler was hit by enemy gunfire and mortally wounded. His extraordinary leadership, infinite courage, and selfless concern for his men saved the lives of a number of his comrades. His actions reflect great credit upon himself and uphold the highest traditions of the military service.

Colonel John Philip Geraci is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame in recognition of his selfless loyalty and dedication during his 36-year military career that significantly impacted the conduct of Ranger Training and the future of Ranger unit operations. Prior the first of three tours in Vietnam in 1960 with the fledgling Military Assistance Advisory Group (MAAG), COL Geraci had had already experienced WWII as a USMC Corporal from 1943-45. After being commissioned a 2LT in the U.S. Army in 1949, he led an infantry platoon in the Korean War 1950-51 where he was twice awarded the Silver Star; the Bronze Star for Valor and the Purple Heart. After Korea, he served in assignments where he honed his leadership skills and advanced an ever-useful set of important language skills. As a 32 year old CPT he attended the Infantry officer Advanced Course at Fort Benning. While there, he had the ambition and insight to attend the Airborne Course and Ranger School so as to add additional skills to those already learned in combat. He finished his degree in education, and by fate or design, was assigned to Fort Bragg where he began mapping his career on the ground floor of innovative Special Forces / Special Operations assignments. COL Geraci served three tours in Vietnam totaling 44 months – as an Advisor with the Military Assistance Advisory Group (MAAG); Detachment XO, 5th SFGA; Senior Advisor, MACV Advisory Team 50, 44th STZ; Commander, 3rd Battalion, 506th, 101st Airborne Division; and Commander, 1st Brigade, 9th Inf Division during which time he was awarded the Silver Star twice again and awarded numerous other awards for valor and merit. Upon return to Fort Benning he was assigned as Director of Company Operations. Later as Ranger Department Director he influenced numerous structural improvements and noteworthy program changes. He later commanded 1st Special Forces Group in Okinawa and prior to retirement was the Chief of the U.S. Military Mission in Zaire. COL Geraci Lived the Ranger Creed and then some!

Command Sergeant Major (r) Michael T. Hall entered the Army Aug 1976. He was assigned to A Co, 1st Battalion (Ranger), 75th Infantry. 1983, he was assigned to the Citadel as ROTC Military Science III Instructor / Advisor, and Cordell Airborne Ranger Company. 1985, he was assigned to 1st Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment. 1995, he was assigned to 3d Battalion, 187th Infantry Regiment, 101st Airborne (Air Assault) Division as the battalion Command Sergeant Major. In June 1996, he was assigned as the 75th Ranger Regiment Command Sergeant Major. In May 2000, he was assigned as the Command Sergeant Major of the Joint Special Operations Command. In November 2001, he was assigned as the Command Sergeant Major of the Special Operations Command at Fort Bragg, NC. CSM Hall retired in Jul 2008 after 32 years, but was recalled in August 2009 as the Command Sergeant Major for the International Security Assistance Force, NATO, and served until Sep 2010, retiring again October 2010. CSM Hall worked for the McChrystal Group from January 2011 to 2014. He has been involved with operational deployments; the Multi-National Force Observer Mission-Sinai, Operation Just Cause, Operation Uphold Democracy, Operation Desert Storm, Phase III, Operation Joint Endeavor , Operation Iraqi Freedom, Operation Enduring Freedom. His Awards and Decorations include: Distinguished Service Medal, Defense Superior Service Medal with OLC, Legion of Merit with OLC, Bronze Star Medal, Meritorious Service Medal (2OLC), Joint Service Commendation Medal, Army Commendation Medal (4OLC), Army Achievement Medal (3OLC), Good Conduct Medal-10th Award, National Defense Service Medal 2nd award, Armed Forces Expeditionary Medal with Arrowhead and Star, Global War on Terrorism Expeditionary Medal, Global War on Terrorism Service Medal, Humanitarian Service Medal, NCO Professional Development Ribbon with numeral 4, Multinational Force and Observers Medal, Southwest Asia Service Medal, Army Service Ribbon, Kuwaiti Liberation Medal, Afghanistan Campaign Medal w/Campaign Star, Overseas Service Ribbon, NATO Afghanistan Service Medal-ISAF, the Army Superior Unit Award, and the Joint Meritorious Unit Award (1OLC). He has: Expert Infantryman's Badge, Combat Infantryman's Badge, and Combat Action Badge, Jordanian, Dutch, German, and British Jump Wings, Master Parachutist Badge with Combat Star, Ranger Tab, Pathfinder Badge, Military Free Fall Parachutist Badge, and Air Assault Badge. CSM Hall has a BS in Political Science from NY State Regents University. CSM Hall is a recipient of the COL Aaron Bank Award from Association of Special Operations Professionals for achievement.

Colonel (Ret) Thomas M. Henry is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his 33 years of distinguished military service with Ranger, Airborne, and Special Forces units. In 1945, he began his career in the Army, serving as part of the occupation force of Japan. In 1948, he was commissioned a 2LT in the United States Army Reserves. In 1950, he was called to active duty and served with the 8th Cavalry. His other assignments included Commander of the 2d Ranger Company, (TNG), in Dahlonega, GA., Ranger Department Operations Officer, Ft. Benning, GA. In 1962 he was served as the Senior Advisor (MAAG) to the Ranger Training Center, Trung Lap, Vietnam, where he successfully established a Ranger training program for the newly formed Vietnamese Rangers. COL Henry then became Special Forces qualified and served a second tour in Vietnam as the 5th SFG Operations Officer. Other assignments encompass the US Strike Command, MacDill AFB, Task Force 7 to the Congo, Battalion Commander, 3rd Battalion, 325th Parachute Infantry, Office of the assistant Chief of Staff for Force Development, Joint Causality Command, Vientiane, Laos, and US Army Mission, Tehran, Iran. In 1976 COL Henry was assigned to the JFK Special Warfare Center at Ft. Bragg, NC as Director of Combat Developments. In this capacity COL Henry developed the concept briefing for establishing an Army Counter-Terrorist Unit later called "Delta Force" - he included the US Army 75th Infantry (Ranger) as an important part in this concept. The concept briefing was approved by the Army Chief of Staff. This is how the 75th Infantry Rangers became part of SOCOM.

Colonel Skip Chittenden is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for performance, courage, and leadership in critical and sensitive positions. In 1959, as a ROTC DMG, he was commissioned a RA 2LT of Infantry, beginning his 29 - year extraordinary career. 2LT Chittenden graduated from Ranger School in Nov, 1959, and was quick to spread Ranger training throughout the Army. He did that at the platoon through brigade level. US Army Europe chose him to head a MTT to start a Ranger School for the Iranian Army. Assigned to Benning Ranger Command, US Army Ranger Department, he taught 34 of the then 37 subjects in the Program of Instruction. He edited the Patrolling FMs and authored the original "Ranger Handbook." He served as the Principle Instructor of the "Rangers in Action" Team which performed at Ft Benning, Memphis, TN, and at Governor's Island, NY. In VN, Ranger CPT Chittenden was the S1, S4, and then commanded Co A, 2/7th Cavalry Regiment, 1st Cavalry Division (Airmobile), specializing in the Ranger operations of patrolling and night area-ambushing in Phan Theit Province. The battalion was awarded the Presidential Unit Citation. COL Chittenden specialized in the "Command, Operations, Training, and Planning" field. For his courage, he was awarded the Soldier's Medal for Heroism, Bronze Star w/V device, Vietnam Cross of Gallantry w/Bronze Star, and four Bronze Stars for combat actions. During his second tour in Vietnam as a Major, he was the Senior Advisor, 4th Vietnamese Ranger Group and, later, the 41st Vietnamese Ranger Group. He became the Deputy Senior Advisor, Ranger Command, and Military Region IV. During his battalion command, he stressed Ranger standards, PT, patrolling, & night operations. As a colonel in the Individual Training Division, DA DCSOPS, he projected and resourced the Army's Individual Training down to the MOS level, including Ranger School and was awarded the Legion of Merit. As the Senior Advisor for the California National Guard, he greatly improved the readiness of the Infantry Division, the MP Brigade, the Medical Brigade, the Area Support Command, & the Troop Command. He retired in 1989. He is a DA Ambassador for the Combat Related Special Comp program. COL Chittenden still spreads the "Ranger Spirit!"

Command Sergeant Major James P. Regan, United States Army, Retired, is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his leadership, service to Army Rangers, superb accomplishments, and stellar service to the United States of America. Ranger Regan was actively recruited to first join Company E, 52d Infantry (Long Range Patrol) with the 1st Cavalry Division in Vietnam. Shortly after his arrival, this unit was re-designated Company H (Ranger) 75th Infantry (Airborne), which was to become the most decorated Ranger unit during the Vietnam conflict. Ranger Regan continued with his excellent service as a Ranger Instructor and later the Operations NCO at the Mountain Ranger Camp, Ranger Department, in Dahlonega, Georgia. Ranger Regan again went to Vietnam and was an adviser to the 76th Vietnamese Ranger Battalion, 41st Vietnamese Ranger Group. Ranger Regan started as a Ranger Student and received his Ranger Tab, went to combat with a 75th Infantry Ranger unit, was a Ranger instructor, and an adviser to the Vietnamese Rangers - the complete cycle for any Ranger. Ranger Regan's integrity, leadership, and Military Intelligence background, and unblemished career, led him to be chosen by the Sergeant Major of the Army to be the first CSM of the Joint Service White House Communications Agency (WHCA) which supports the President of the United States. Ranger Regan is worthy of this honor, and a perfect example for all Rangers to emulate.

Command Sergeant Major Jimmy L. Broyles served admirably in both military and law enforcement careers. In 1970 he served with Cl L 75th inf Abn Ranger, 101st Abn Div, VN. He volunteered for a tour extension, assigned to Co H 75th Inf Abn Ranger, 1st Cav Div VN. He returned to CONUS and assigned to Co B 75th Inf Abn Ranger, Seventh Corp. Broyles was an "Original" member of the Co C 1/75th in 1974. His active duty career saw service in III Corp and Ft Hood, NCO Academy, and Co A 1st Bn OSUT 1st Student Training Bde. Upon retirement, Broyles served in the transport of nuclear weapons. He served with Texas Law Enforcement at both the County and Federal levels and recognized as Law Enforcement Officer of the Year by the FBI. Broyles enlisted in the TX Army National Guard with C. C 3;144th Inf TXARNG (1SG), continuing duties as 1SG with Co B 1/143rd Inf Abn TXARNG (returning to Airborne Status), then to Co C 3/144th Inf TXARNG (1SG) and as TX adopted the Abrams Tank to HHC 1/112th Armor TXARNG (1SG) and JJC 3rd. Bde. 49th Armored Div TXARNG (Opns SGM). As the nation initiated Operation Enduring Freedom, Broyles deployed to the Balkans as the CSM of 3rd Bde, 49th Armored Div TXARNG, performing admirably with Task Force Falcon. CSM Broyles retired Nov 2011 at age 60. He retired as the last active duty combat Ranger from the Viet Nam War, with 30 years of total service.

General (R) Stanley A. McChrystal is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his career of service to and promotion of the 75th Ranger Regiment, Special Operations Community, and the Ranger Community. GEN McChrystal graduated West Point in 1976. He began his military career as a platoon leader in the 82nd Airborne Division at Fort Bragg, North Carolina. Over the course of his career, he held several leadership and staff positions in the Army Special Forces, 75th Ranger Regiment, 82nd Airborne Division and the XVIII Airborne Corps. GEN (R) McChrystal served in the 75th Ranger Regiment at every level of command. He served the Ranger Regiment as the Alpha Company Commander for 3 Battalion, 75 Ranger Regiment, 3/75 LNO, 3/75 Operations Officer, Battalion Commander for 2nd Battalion 75 Ranger Regiment, and the 10th Regimental Commander of the 75th Ranger Regiment. Key commands consist of Chief of Staff – Operations Afghanistan; JSOC Commander; Director of Joint Staff; Commander, US and International Forces - Afghanistan. Awards/ Decorations: Defense Distinguished Service Medal, Defense Superior Service Medal (with Oak Leaf Cluster), Legion of Merit (with 2 Oak Leaf Clusters), Bronze Star Medal, Defense Meritorious Service Medal, Meritorious Service Medal (with 3 Oak Leaf Clusters), Army Commendation Medal, Army Achievement Medal, Expert Infantryman Badge, Master Parachutist Badge, Ranger Tab, Special Forces Tab, Joint Chiefs of Staff Identification Badge. GEN (R) McChrystal's education consists of Master of Arts - National Security and Strategic Studies from United States Naval War College and a Master of Science - International Relations from Salve Regina University. GEN (R) McChrystal's service to the 75th Ranger Regiment, the Special Operations Community and the US Army set the standard for all Rangers' past, present and future to follow.

Lieutenant Colonel Rembert G. Rollison is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his valorous actions, exceptional leadership and selfless service during his distinguished career as a Ranger Officer. He served two combat tours in the Republic of Vietnam; leading his men by personal example on countless occasions in the face of intense enemy fire. His calm coolness and immeasurable courage under hostile fire was absolutely remarkable. He led his men from the front, always positioning himself where he was most effective. His finely honed skills as a woodsman and innate ability to accurately predict the enemy's intentions served him well in combat. He carried a 12 gage shotgun which he used to bring 'scunion' on the enemy with deadly accurate fire. He made his men feel confident and almost invincible. They always pressed hard to keep up with him. During the battle for Firebase Ripcord, he was viewed as the most effective leader present. His valor in combat was legendary. He always led with confidence, inspiring his men to follow. He lived the Ranger Creed and exemplified every characteristic and quality expected of a Ranger. At each stage in his life, no matter how challenging the situation, Ranger Rollison was a role model encouraging those around him to excel. He exuded a calming confidence in the presence of chaos. He was more than tactically proficient: he was cunning, smart and utterly courageous. He cared deeply for his soldiers and for those with whom he served. He endured every suffering they experienced. He exposed himself to enemy fire so that others would not have to. Twice he served as a Ranger Instructor and Tac Officer passing on to future leaders those lessons necessary to survive in combat that he learned from experience. He served his nation with honor and distinction for over 20 years in ever increasing positions of responsibility at Platoon, Company, Battalion, Brigade, Division and Joint Operations levels. He thrived on leadership challenges meeting every one successfully. He was truly a superlative warrior richly deserving to join those honored in the Ranger Hall of Fame.

Lieutenant Colonel Rex G. Masters is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his exemplary conduct in combat as an Airborne Ranger and his unwavering and effective leadership as a four-time President of Airborne Rangers of the Korean War. He volunteered for the newly forming Airborne Ranger Companies in the fall of 1950, joined 3rd Airborne Ranger Company on 18 Dec 1950, and graduated from the exceedingly tough Ranger training on 13 January 1951. After three weeks of minus 30 degree winter training at Camp Carson, CO, he arrived in Korea on 24 March 1951. His first major combat action was on 11 April 1951 with 3rd Company who suffered four KIA and 24 WIA at "Bloody Nose Ridge"- which was more casualties than any other division rifle company in war to date. Masters was with 3rd Company throughout his combat time until all six Airborne Ranger Companies were transferred into the 187th Airborne RCT on 1 August 1951. He was commissioned as a 2LT on 5 April 1955 and served as a firing battery platoon leader and battery commander in several Redstone and other missile commands. In October 1964, he served as an RF-PF Advisor of Kien Phong Province, Viet Nam where he was awarded His 2nd Combat Infantry Badge. He served in senior officer artillery assignments in the United States and Korea until he retired on 1 September 1972 as a LTC. Masters has served as the President of the Airborne Rangers of the Korean War four times, two times from 1993-1997 and two more times from 2011 to present. During the ARKW reunion in 1995 in Washington D.C., concurrently with dedication of the Korean War Memorial, he led the Rangers during the march of the Korean War units. He attended the placing of the wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier by the President of the United States and was invited to the White House for the welcome of the South Korean President.

Sergeant Major Gregory A. Matteo is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for a long and meritorious service to the United States of America, while conducting combat operations in three wars. Ranger Matteo began his career with the U.S. Army in the 162nd Infantry Regiment of the 41st Division, serving in World War Two. Ranger Matteo served as a Combat Medic in the Pacific Theater. He volunteered during the Korean War for the newly formed Airborne Ranger Infantry Companies. Ranger Matteo served with distinction in the 4th Ranger Infantry Company (Airborne) in Korea as a Squad Leader and later as Platoon Sergeant. Ranger Matteo valiantly led his men during the combat jump at Munsan-ni, on the daring raid at the H'wachon Dam and later during the action of Task Force Croft. In 1953 Ranger Matteo was selected to the U.S. Special Forces. In 1960 Ranger Matteo was dispatched to the Republic of Vietnam at Na Trang. His mission was to set up Ranger Training for the Army of the Republic of Vietnam at Na Trang. Ranger Matteo returned to the Republic of Vietnam for a second tour with company A, 5th Special Forces Group (Airborne). After his military career ended he worked for the Department of Defense. For the next sixteen years Ranger Matteo served his Nation in many foreign areas of the world, including Southeast Asia, where he trained W.S. personnel in sensitive undertakings. Ranger Matteo served his country for a total of forty years of distinguished military and civil service. Ranger Matteo has demonstrated a selfless dedication to the principles which have been extolled in the Ranger Creed. All who have served with him describe him as the ideal Ranger, courageous, competent and daring.

Major Robert Bischoff is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his distinguished lifetime of selfless dedication to Ranger ideals and the profession of arms. Thorough training, prompt obedience, and focus on the objective characterized his approach to every mission. In war and peace, Major Bischoff showed himself to be the model Ranger. His accomplishments as a warrior include earning two Silver Stars, the Soldier's Medal, and the Bronze Star for Valor. While serving in Vietnam, he led the way at great personal risk on several assaults against fortified enemy positions in the face of intense and accurate fire. His concern for fellow soldiers and "leave no man behind" attitude were evidenced clearly as he pulled a pilot from a burning helicopter. Ranger Bischoff proved his exceptional leadership and extensive training skills during four tours of duty with the Ranger Training Command. His extraordinary achievements included serving on the "Rangers In Action" demonstration team that performed for President John F. Kennedy in 1961. His command presence, calm demeanor, and maturity beyond his years served him well as a Principal Instructor of a multiple day Ranger Training Exercise and also as a Ranger Class Tactical Officer. Ranger Bischoff's technical and tactical competence allowed him to serve with distinction as senior advisor to the Vietnamese Ranger Command while still a Captain. Ranger Bischoff's superlative accomplishments, valorous actions, and concerned leadership have cemented his place among the outstanding Rangers in the Hall of Fame.

CW4 Russell L. McIntyre is inducted in to the Ranger Hall of Fame for his exceptional commitment to the U.S. Army and the nation while demonstrating and achieving excellence and an unparalleled commitment to the Ranger Creed. He is a combat veteran whose 24 year active duty career began in 1968, when he enlisted in the Army and served as a Leader of a Combined Tactical Human Intelligence Team assigned to the 173rd Airborne Brigade in the Republic of Vietnam. While assigned to the U.S. Army Special Warfare Center and School, Mr. McIntyre was among those credited with establishing the now infamous Survival, Evasion, & Resistance Escape (SERE) course. While serving as the Chief Targeting Officer for 75th Ranger Regiment he provided intelligence to contingency deployments and nationally directed operations. CW4 McIntyre was assigned to the Special Operations Command Europe where he wrote the Intelligence Estimates for Operations Desert Shield/Desert Storm before his retirement in 1994. CW4 McIntyre received many awards for valor and service including the Legion of Merit, Joint and Service Meritorious Service Medals, and the Bronze Star with oak leaf cluster. In 1997 Mr. McIntyre recommitted to support the nation as a DoD civilian in the Office of Secretary of Defense. In 2003, he joined the Defense Intelligence Agency, helping establish the Special Collections Coordination Center. He deployed to Iraq supporting the Multi-National Coalition-Iraq J3 Counter Improvised Explosive Device Cell where he led the creation of the Weapons Technical Intelligence capability. In 2008 he was promoted to a Defense Intelligence Senior Executive Service as Chief, Forensic Intelligence Office Directorate for MASINT and Technical Collection. Mr. McIntyre retired in 2014 after 44 years of total government service. He was recognized for his contribution in the takedown of Geronimo and was awarded the DIA Director's Award for Excellence. Mr. McIntyre is the embodiment of the Ranger Creed, displaying the intestinal fortitude required to fight on to the Ranger objective and complete the mission.

Sergeant First Class Taft Yates is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his long and distinguished career as a Ranger Leader. SFC Yates began his Ranger Career in 1975 and over the next 20 years served in every position in a Ranger Unit from rifleman to 1SG. He led his Rangers in two combat jumps. First in Grenada, in support of Operation Urgent Fury (October 1983) and again into Panama in support of Operation Just Cause (December 1989). He knew from the beginning that he wanted to be and Airborne Ranger and when given the opportunity to serve with the newly formed 2nd Battalion 75th Ranger Regiment, he knew that was where he belonged. It was not good enough for him to be a Ranger, he had to be the best Ranger he could possibly be. After talking with those who served with him there is no doubt that he accomplished the mission. "He was the consummate Ranger NCO. His preparedness and attention to every facet of the operation is legendary. No detail was too small or overlooked and he passed this value on to those who would rise through the ranks and eventually become the leadership of what was to become the 75th Ranger Regiment." Ranger Yates constantly deployed on Ranger exercises from Europe to Central America and all over the Pacific Northwest. When it was time for combat, his Rangers with him in the lead energetically met the enemy and showed them they were better trained and fought with all their might on to the Ranger Objective. He had the opportunity to do this twice, as a Squad Leader and then as a Platoon Sergeant both with Combat Jumps, something rarely done once. SFC Yates continues his dedication to the principles of the Ranger Creed long after his retirement through Law Enforcement, culminating in his selection as Chief of Police for Ellis, Kansas, and the promotion of Ranger History in Kansas and throughout the United States of America.

Brigadier General William R. Bond is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. During WWII, in the North Africa Campaign, Lt William Ross Bond volunteered for duty with the famed "Darby's rangers" and joined the 1st Ranger Battalion in time to lead a company onto the beach at Maiori, just west of Salerno, in early September 1943. Once the fifth army advance to Naples was well underway, the Rangers were withdrawn to prepare for the next tough, special mission. This turned out to be, for Bond's battalion, a fierce two-week battle for control of the rocky heights above Venafro, deep in the Italian Apennines. When the Rangers at last dislodged the Germans, the way was cleared for the advance of the Fifth Army's right flank. In late January 1944, Captain Bond and his unit landed with the assault waves at Anzio, where the Rangers occupied a critical sector of the allied perimeter, linking the 3rd U.S. and 1st British divisions. On 29-30 January, Darby's Rangers made their gallant but ill-fated night attack to the Appian Way at Cisterna Di Littoria as part of the larger design to break out from the ridge end. Infiltrating the German lines by stealth, the 1st and 3rd Ranger Battalions were on the edge of their objective by dawn, only to find themselves in the midst of German strength, completely cut off from the remainder of the attacking forces. Surrounded by vastly superior strength and subjected to relentless pounding by tanks and artillery; the Rangers fought on for over 5 hours until all ammunition was exhausted. At the time of surrender, casualties had reduced the force to less than half of it original 900 men strength. For his magnificent exploits on that day Captain Bond was awarded the Silver Star. For the next 11 months, Bond was confined at an officer prisoner of war camp at Szubin, Poland. When the Russians breached the line of the Vistula in early January 1945, the allied officers were evacuated westward. On the second night of the move, Bond, his battalion commander (Jack Dobson, now brigadier general, USA-retired) and several others made their escape to find the Russian lines. Six days later, they encountered a Russian armored column. For the next week, Bond's group had the unique distinction of being integrated into the Red Army, as a special reconnaissance detachment, in the drive west. Upon the end of the war, BG Bond had an illustrious career with several command and staff positions.

Command Sergeant Major David R. Dalton is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame Known in throughout the Ranger community, CSM (R) Dalton is one of the many unsung treasures unknown to the American public. CSM (R) career is a testament to a life led as a quiet professional constantly seeking improvement in the war fighting tactics and skills of the modern day Ranger. CSM (R) Dalton volunteered for LRRP duty in Vietnam - after suffering wounds in combat. His professional excellence and personal aptitude allowed him to serve in operational and strategic level position include duties as the NCOIC of a district military assistance team in military region II of Vietnam through the summer of 1972. As a Ranger, CSM Dalton served as a junior NCO in 1st Ranger Battalion followed by assignments as the Ranger Department. His technical and tactical proficiencies were rewarded with duty as the U.S. army's foreign exchange NCO to the Australian infantry Centre in Singleton, New South Wales where he taught marksmanship to NCOs and officers, sniper techniques and marksmanship to selected soldiers as well as squad and platoon light infantry tactics to NCOs and officers. Recognized for his ability to teach and lead diverse formations, CSM Dalton was also selected as the Aco and Bco 1SG at 1st Ranger Battalion and duty as the NCOIC of the Ranger Indoctrination Program. His CSM-billets include 1st Battalion 505th parachute Infantry Regiment at Ft Bragg, NC and then 1st Ranger Battalion, Hunter Army Airfield. Throughout his retirement, CSM Dalton remained active sharing his lessons learned with the active duty Rangers and the Ranger community. He is the embodiment of the Ranger creed, a tenacious warrior with the intellect to effect change that improves organizations.

Command Sergeant Major (Retired) James Earl "Hoot" Gibson is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame Gibson enlisted in the Army in 1962 and began his career as a paratrooper in the 101st Airborne. In 1967, he deployed to Vietnam as a squad leader where he was severely wounded in action, spending a year in hospitals recovering from his extensive wounds, but determined to return to duty. Following successive assignments as a trainer preparing soldiers for their eventual combat duty, CSM Gibson returned to Vietnam as Senior NCO and Team Advisor in MACV. As a Sergeant First Class, he attended Ranger Class 5-73 where he served as the class first sergeant and became the Distinguished Honor Graduate. Already recognized as one of the Army's experienced premier trainers and a distinguished combat veteran, CSM Gibson was among the first NCOs selected for the initial cadre of the first ranger battalion to be activated since World War II. He was deeply involved in the transition of the battalion from formation to its certification as a fully operational and worldwide deployable combat unit. He was instrumental in the actual development and writing of the training objectives (tasks, conditions, and standards) to guide the Ranger Battalion's training program which ultimately changed how the Army trained. He personified the Abrams Charter inspiring his men to "graduate" from the Ranger Battalion and take what they had learned to other units to make the entire Army better. Likewise, CSM Gibson left the Ranger Battalion to serve as a First Sergeant in the 9th and 25th Divisions, a Senior National Guard Advisor, and Battalion Command Sergeant Major in the 172d in Alaska. He applied the same professional dedication to his civilian occupation in law enforcement and security. Throughout, he remained supportive of Ranger associations and especially the Disabled American Veterans as a volunteer mentor and counselor for rangers and other veterans in their negotiating the Veterans Administration process. During and after his military career and his lifetime of service to the Army, his community, and fellow veterans, Command Sergeant Major Gibson has "always endeavored to uphold the prestige, honor, and high esprit de corps of the Rangers" and to instill that sense of duty, accountability, and warrior spirit in others.

Colonel Glynn Walter Hale lived by the Ranger Creed and is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his courageous fame in battle and his magnificent service to the Rangers, the United States Army, and America. Hale was a combat leader who led from the front in performing the many missions given to him while at the same time always taking care of the soldiers under his command. Hale is a man of unparalleled courage. During Hale's 18 months of service in Vietnam, as a rifle platoon leader in the 2/506th Infantry Regiment, 101st Airborne Division, Hale was awarded two Silver Stars and two Purple Hearts, one each for leading an attack against an NVA company sized base camp and for eliminating an NVA position which enabled him and his platoon to recover 2 wounded American soldiers. As a rifle platoon leader, he also earned an ARCOM with/V for clearing a tree line of NVA which led to the recovery of wounded American soldiers. As the Company Commander of C/2/506th Infantry, Hale was awarded a Third Silver Star for assuming command of one of his platoons when the platoon leader was wounded and continuing the fight to include calling in close air strikes from an exposed position, and a Bronze Star with B device for clearing a trench and capturing 2 Viet Cong Soldiers. After Vietnam, Hale took command of the Honor Guard Company (The Old Guard) which conducts the Army and Joint Service ceremonies in Washington, D.C. In Special Forces, Hale served in Thailand training units in the Thai Special Forces. Hale later served as the S-3, Executive Officer, and Acting Commander of the 2nd Battalion (Ranger), 75th Ranger Regiment, at Ft. Benning, GA. Hale served with distinction as the Regimental Commander of the 505th PIR (Parachute Infantry Regiment), 82nd Airborne Division during the invasion of Iraq in Operation Desert Storm after which he retired from the military. Hale worked for several years in the International Business Community before assuming the duties of a middle school math teacher where he influenced and positively shaped the lives of his many young students for many years. Ranger Hale led the way and his courageous leadership is an inspiration to all who know him.

SGM Ronald E. Hart joined the Army at 17 to be an Airborne/Ranger. Served in 1/325th ABG, 82nd Abn. Tried to join 11th Air Assault, but was selected for the Fort Benning Honor Guard Co. Then joined A/1/506, 101st Abn. As an E-4, attended Ranger School – was promoted to E-5 & assigned to the Ranger Dept. In the next 4 yrs was promoted to SSG & SFC; graduated 3rd Army NCO Academy - top 5%; Jumpmaster Course; ITC; & Honor Grad of Pathfinder. Hart helped update the Ranger Hand book; performed Ranger In Action demonstration for Pres Gerald Ford; was PI, Compass Class; and API, Road Marches. Mar 1970 Hart joined Co. F, 75th Rangers as a Pltn SGT. Conducted 6-man, 5-day recons - the 5th day set ambushes. Don "Mad Dog" Purdy, a Team Member, wrote of Hart, "He led by example. He is also one of the bravest leaders I have ever known. He risked his life to save two (downed) pilots. He is a humble, selfless leader. His only hero awards he was ordered to accept. Ron Hart is a Ranger hero!" The Teams conducted numerous classified actions. SOG Hqs coded them "Soap Chips." F Co's enemy KIA count was higher than any Inf Bn in their Inf Div. An ARCOM w/V citation: "PLT SGT Hart led an element to secure a downed helicopter. He took the quickest route from the LZ. In the lead, he spied the enemy, directed the unit to move into the woods. Contact was made ** Hart fired, killed one enemy & wounded another. **; Ranger Hart led from the front, moved his Tm to safety, selflessly stood his ground and shot accurately!" Ranger Hart returned to the Ranger Dept, assigned PI, Cadre Led Recon Ptls & PI teaching Patrol Order. SFC Hart W/Tm were the originals in Ft Bliss to formulate the Desert Phase and was selected as the Ops Officer, Benning Phase - office required CPT (now a Major). Became NCOIC, Morgan Branch. Mar 79 - Oct 80 advised 2nd Scout Bn, Bethel, AK. Advised Armories in 23 remote villages. Served in Army Inf Test Brd , and SGM of Dir, Plans & Trng, Ft. Benning. 1986 -1989 was Sr. Enlisted Adviser, 207th Grp, Alaska. Ranger Hart, a quiet professional, always led from the front with exceptional courage!

Lieutenant General P. K. "Ken" Keen career as a Ranger includes 18 years on airborne status in command of Light Airborne Infantry, Ranger, Special Forces, Military Group and Army Component units. His commands include a Special Forces Detachment (SCUBA) in 3rd Battalion, 7th Special Forces Group; Company and Battalion Commands in the 82nd Airborne Division; Command of 1st Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment; Command of the 75th Ranger Regiment; Command of U.S. Military Group Bogota, Colombia; Command of U.S. Army South (USARSO); and Command of Joint Task Force Haiti - Operation Unified Response. LTG (R) participated in Operation JUST CAUSE as the Assistant S3 of the 75th Ranger Regiment and was Commander, Ranger Task Force during Operation DESERT STORM as part of Joint Special Operations Command. From September 2007 to September 2009, he served as the Director of the U.S. European Command Plans and Operations Center and the EUCOM Chief of Staff. LTG (R) Keen's final assignment was as Military Deputy Commander of the U.S. Southern Command, with responsibility for 32 countries and territories in the Caribbean and Central and South America. His awards and decorations include the Army Distinguished Service Medal, Defense Superior Service Medal, Legion of Merit, Special Forces Tab, Ranger Tab, Pathfinder Badge, Combat SCUBA Diver, Combat Infantry Badge, Expert Infantry Badge and Master Parachutist Badge. LTG (R) Keen continues to lead the way developing the nation's next generation of business and civic leaders as a professor and the Associate Dean of Leadership Development at Emory University's Goizueta School of Business in Atlanta, Georgia.

Ranger Linderer has been referred to as a Combat Ranger's Ranger by those he served with. He arrived in Vietnam on 6 June 1968 and spent twelve (12) months as a patrol member in his 75th Ranger Regiment company. In that year he went from a PFC to a SGT. During that period he was awarded the Silver Star, Bronze Star w/V Device and Oak Leaf Cluster, Purple Heart w/ Oak Leaf Cluster, and the Army Commendation Medal w/V Device and Oak Leaf Cluster. He truly practiced "Rangers Lead The Way." On 20 November 1968, then SPC Linderer, and his Team ambushed a Ten (10) man NVA Patrol, eliminating nine (9) of the enemy. While en-route to the extraction LZ, the point man was seriously wounded by enemy automatic weapons fire. SPC Linderer immediately initiated a heavy volume of automatic weapon fire and grenades toward the enemy position, allowing two of his team mates to pull the wounded man to safety. SPC Linderer was wounded in the legs but continued to lay down automatic weapons fire and grenades, allowing the Medi-Vac chopper to land and load the wounded team member. SPC Linderer then called in air support to turn back the company size NVA element that was attacking the remainder of the team. An NVA Claymore mine detonated ten (10) meters away, killing three Team members and wounding the remaining eight. SPC Linderer, although badly wounded in the legs, maintained his firing position by the radio, and continued to fight until he was extracted about one hour later. Ranger Linderer wanted to do the best job he was capable of as a Ranger, after speaking with those he served with in Vietnam, there is no doubt that he accomplished his mission and "Left No One Behind." He continues his dedication to the Ranger Creed long after his military service, bringing Rangers of all eras together and mentoring Ranger authors. RLTW!

CPT Stephen C. Maguire is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame in recognition of his unique and unparalleled career focused on leading, guiding, mentoring and counseling and Soldiers and their families. While Recon Platoon Leader, 6/31 Infantry, 9th Infantry Division on November 6, 1969 Maguire was critically wounded, including total blindness. He was hospitalized in Vietnam, Japan and eventually at Walter Reed Army Medical Center where after 17 months of hospitalization in March 1971 he medically retired. With uncompromising Ranger sprit, he returned to civilian life and over the next years continued his studies becoming a counseling psychologist working in the areas of mental health, alcohol addiction and substance abuse program in Ireland and Germany. Returning to the States in 1990 he specialized in community- based care for adults with mental retardation and a decade later returned to work for the U.S. Government in Arlington, VA. In 2007, in the wake of serious turmoil regarding the care given to newly wounded soldiers, Maguire was asked to head up a new department that would focus on addressing many of the needs recommended by Presidential and Congressional committees. As Director of the then new Soldier Family Assistance Center (SFAC) at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center, Maguire established and organized operations; and wrote and implemented operational policy and procedures for the provision of comprehensive, integrated and compassionate care and quality-of-life services to severely Wounded Warriors and their visiting Family Members. His success led the Army to duplicate this model in 30 other Army hospitals and medical centers. Through the next six years, Maguire directed the department, which served the needs of many hundreds of the most severely injured, ill and wounded Soldiers, together with thousands of their family members. Given that CPT Maguire's Army career as a Soldier ended with his medical retirement at Walter Reed in 1971, it was supremely fitting that his Army civilian career be concluded at the very same place in 2013, while serving to better the care provided to Soldiers wounded in our current wars including those from the Ranger community.

Command Sergeant Major (Retired) Jeffrey Mellinger's 39 years of active duty Army service is defined by career dedicated to living the Ranger Creed. CSM (R) Mellinger's career is bookended by entry into active duty via the Vietnam draft and retirement after 17 years of service as a Command Sergeant Major. Throughout his years, he has left an indelible mark on the 75th Ranger Regiment. CSM (R) Mellinger served in nearly every enlisted leadership position as a member of the 75th Ranger Regiment, beginning with his arrival to 2d Ranger Battalion as a rifleman and earning assignment as a Platoon Sergeant and Weapons Platoon Leader. CSM (R) Mellinger's was selected and served as one of the first team leaders of the Ranger Regiment Reconnaissance Detachment (RRD). CSM (R) Mellinger was a part of a dedicated group of quiet professionals that developed the operating procedures for RRD. The mission success of the RRD led to the formation of a more expansive Ranger Reconnaissance Company. After leaving RRD to live Abrams Charter in a variety of leadership positions to include CSM, 3-10 IN, Fort Leonard Wood, Missouri; CSM (R) Mellinger returned to the Ranger Regiment as the 1st Ranger Battalion CSM. Our Army continued to seek the leadership of CSM (R) Mellinger for assignments that put him in direct contact with our Soldiers and the enemy. CSM (R) Mellinger served in nominative CSM assignments that included U.S Army Japan and 9th Theater Support Command, First U.S. Army, and Multi-National Forces-Iraq, and U.S. Army Material Command CSM. In retirement, CSM (R) Mellinger continues to remain an active part of the Ranger community. He continues to live the Ranger Creed by routinely volunteers his time and resources to assist in the development of Ranger leaders and their families. He has devoted his time to a number of Ranger transition and family initiatives to include the Gallant Few, Inc. CSM (R) Mellinger is a Distinguished Member of the 75th Ranger Regiment and a member of the Orders of Saint Maurice (Primicerius), Combat Spur, and Saint Barbara. He is a General Brehon B. Somervell Medal of Excellence and National Infantry Association Doughboy recipient.

MSG Jesus David Moncada is inducted into the US Army Ranger Hall of Fame in recognition of a lifetime of service to the nation and during which he served as an example of a life well led in the Ranger tradition. MSG Moncada served in a variety of capacities for the United States, including as a team member and team leader in the Rangers (G Company (Ranger) 75th Infantry) during the Vietnam War, Ranger School instructor, the California National Guard and the Defense Investigative Services of the Department of Defense. MSG Moncada is admired and respected by all those with whom he served, both subordinates and superiors, as a quiet but very effective leader. No more effective leader than MSG Moncada can be found, both in his military and post-military lives. He demonstrated exceptional leadership skills as a LRRP in Vietnam and was quickly named a team leader. As a team leader, he led many missions in Vietnam, often involving firefights with the enemy. He served as Team Leader of the highly regarded Team Hawaii, consisting of Hawaiians, Native Americans and Hispanics. Twice, while serving as team leader, he was wounded during firefights. He nonetheless maintained control of his teams, displaying uncommon valor and courage, providing effective covering fire while his team was able to reach the extraction point where they were lifted to safety. His exemplary leadership skills and "lessons learned" were easily applied to his time as Assistant NCOIC at the G Company Recondo School and especially as patrolling instructor at the Mountain Ranger Camp. Moreover, after serving in the California National Guard, he became an effective investigator for the Defense Investigative Services of the Department of Defense, a sensitive position requiring not only exceptional leadership skills, but also his ability to deal effectively with special operations groups in Europe. He serves as a positive role model to all those who strive to become Rangers. MSG Moncada's post-service life remains committed to his beloved Rangers, serving as co- founder, board member and officer of the G Company Ranger Association, and to his family. MSG Moncada truly exemplifies the Ranger Creed.

Ranger Passanisi is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame in recognition of his dedicated service as a Merrill's Marauder and member of the 475th Infantry (MARS Task Force) in the China- Burma-India Theater. Ranger Passanisi was awarded the Bronze Star Medal for exemplary conduct in ground combat against the armed enemy on or about 20 February 1944 in the China- Burma-India Theater of Operations while assigned as Technician Fourth Grade, 5307th Composite Unit (Provisional). When the Marauders reached the Myitkyina airstrip in May 1944, RGR Passanisi was fighting mite typhus, malaria and dysentery. By June 1944, he had lost 60 pounds. A temperature that soared to 105 sent him to the 20th General Hospital for a week. Ranger Passanisi volunteered to return to Myitkyina within 24 hours after his release from the hospital, where he maintained the forward telephone switchboard that was constantly under fire. On 1 July 1944 that he received wounds resulting in his first Purple Heart. He was at Myitkyina when the town fell August 2, 1944. Discharged from the Army on 10 July 1945, RGR Passanisi continues to serve the Marauders as the official historian and a spokesperson for the Merrill's Marauders Association. RGR Passanisi devotes hundreds of hours at the National Archives in Washington D.C. researching orders and supporting documents to confirm or deny individuals who claim service as a Marauder. RGR Passanisi's service as the historian was instrumental in a decade's long effort that culminated in the 2011 presentation of awards and decorations to 33 families of Marauders killed in action in 1944, as well as identification of the remains of three Marauders recovered in Burma and interred at Arlington in July 2010. The Marauders were listed as Missing in action on 23 May 1944 when their aerial resupply aircraft never returned. Through the design of the Merrill's Marauders award winning website and service as the editor of the "Burman News", the association's newsletter, RGR Passanisi has dedicated his life to keep the memory and achievements of the Marauders alive. RANGERS LEAD THE WAY!

Staff Sergeant Raymond "Jack" Schuder is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his World War II combat efforts during sustained actions with the 1st Ranger Battalion and the 3rd Ranger Battalion; his many attempted escapes from German POW Camp Stalag 3B in Furstenberg, Prussia; his many contributions to the Ranger Battalions Associations; and his significant financial and time donations to the training of future U S Army Ranger officers. SSG Schuder was an infantryman in A Company of the 1st Ranger Battalion, and participated in the El Guettar raid for which the 1st Ranger Battalion received a Presidential Unit Citation. SSG Schuder was later in F Company of the 3rd Ranger Battalion, and participated in the capture and defense of the Chiunzi Pass and Sorrento Peninsula for which the 3rd Ranger Battalion received a Presidential Unit Citation. SSG Schuder participated in three combat beach landings – Licato, Sicily; Maiori (Salerno), Italy; and Anzio, Italy. Surrounded by overwhelming German forces, SSG Schuder was captured at Cisterna along with most of the 3rd Ranger Battalion. After his capture, he continuously displayed Ranger drive and a commitment to escape from the German POW camp at Stalag 3B in Furstenberg, Prussia, and suffered from harsh beatings after each unsuccessful attempt. SSG Schuder continued to support the Ranger name and causes after his discharge from the Army in October 1945 by joining and leading within the World War II Ranger Battalions Association. SSG Schuder was awarded the coveted William O. Darby Award for his contributions to this Ranger association in 1988. He also developed a rigorous Ranger training program for the ROTC students at Sam Houston State University using his own funds, property, and time to properly instruct the ROTC cadets on Ranger combat actions. He, along with his wife, made significant financial donations to Sam Houston State University in order to endow an annual scholarship for needy students within the Sam Houston State University Ranger Company, which to his honor became known as "Schuder's Rangers." SSG Schuder lived the Ranger Creed. He was, and through his legacy will forever be, a Ranger who led the way.

SMG Tommy Shook's entire life has been one of selfless service to otir nation. This distinguished Ranger has energetically fought the enemies of our country, in and out of uniform, during a jo0rney that started with hid enlistment in 1960, continued to two tours in Vietnam, then being chosen as 1SG of Company B, 1st Battalion Rangers, and finally a tour in support of the State .Department in Iraq, 2013. Along the way he has distinguished himself in all forms of combat, training and leadership. In 1978, then 1SG Shook, was handpickd by then LTC Joe Stringham and then CSM Glenn Morrell as 1SG of B/1-75. This was a critical period for both 1st and 2nd Ranger. Battalions as they were the tip-ofthe-spear in the rapidly evolving war on terror. 1st Bn was short Rangr qualified NCO's to the point where it was impacting on unit readiness. LTC Stringham and CSM Morrell knew 1SG Shook personally. They knew of his distinguished combat record and his ability to train soldiers for combat. In order to accept the assignment he attended Rariger School at the tender age of 38 years and was Honor Graduate of RC 9-78 as well as rc?iVing tl)e Merrill's Marauder Award.He would lead the way at Company level in the 1st Battalion Ranger, redeveloping and redefining the role of the US Army NCO in what would evolve into the 75th Ranger Regiment. SM Tommy Shook continues to live his life in the highest standards of the Ranger Creed and epitomizes the motto "Rangers Lead. the WAY."

Ranger Snow is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame in recognition of his heroism, valor outstanding accomplishments, and strong leadership abilities in combat. On 14 July 1970, Ranger Snow distinguished himself by valorous action while serving as a Reconnaissance Team Leader for a seven (7) man patrol near Bong Son. Upon moving his men into an ambush site near an enemy base camp, he spotted a 30 man enemy element within 50 meters of his team. He alerted his men by initiating fire upon the enemy force. Under heavy fire from the enemy, he remained exposed to better observe and direct fires against the enemy. Discovering he could not communicate with his headquarters, he established communications with an unidentified aircraft on an emergency radio frequency and requested air support. When the gunships arrived he directed the aircraft fires accurately to disrupt and rout the enemy. His action aided the team in killing seven enemy and capturing numerous equipment with no friendly casualties. In October 1970, Ranger Snow volunteered to accompany a helicopter dispatched from LZ English to search for 21 personnel in danger of drowning. Flying in pre-dawn darkness in a driving rain, he located the beleaguered element in the branches of a tree that was surrounded by the swift current of a flooded river. Ignoring the dangers posed by the poor flying conditions, he returned to LZ English to rig aluminum ladders to be used in the extraction of the endangered paratroopers. After rigging and checking this equipment, he flew back to the flooded area and descended from a hovering helicopter into the debris laden waters of the swollen stream. Struggling to maintain his footing in the fast current, he assisted the 21 exhausted personnel in mounting the ladders to the helicopters above. After all personnel were safely aboard he rigged their rucksacks and weapons for extraction and secured the equipment to the waiting helicopter. After the men and equipment were loaded, he was lifted out of the flood area and flown back to LZ English while clinging to the aluminum ladder that dangled below the helicopter. Ranger Snow is the epitome of a Ranger Noncommissioned Officer and a role model for GEN Creighton Abrams' Ranger Charter.

LTC (R) James M. Tucker is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his leadership of Soldiers, dedicated service to our nation and continued contributions to his local community for over 55 years.
