Jim Tucker has always lived the Ranger Creed. Ranger School made him a better leader and it changed his life. He knew there was no other life for him but as an Infantry leader. During his assignment at the Mountain Ranger Camp, Tucker learned the fine art of teaching, coaching and mentoring our future leaders. His tour reinforced the need of positive leadership under tough, demanding conditions. When a helicopter crashed at night, Jim Tucker earned the Soldiers Medal for his actions recovering the Rangers inside. In his next assignment overseas, Tucker was selected by his command to attend the Royal Marine Commando Course. He graduated from this rigorous course with the award of the Commando Medal. It was during his tour in Vietnam that he learned the true depth and breadth of leadership in combat. He earned two Purple Hearts on this tour. During one night operation gone bad, Ranger Tucker followed the Ranger Creed to never leave a fallen comrade. He earned a Silver Star for going out to recover the Soldiers from a unit in contact. This proven combat leader was selected to command the Florida Ranger Camp in 1969. His dynamic personal example of leadership set the example for others to follow. It was during this time that Ranger Tucker was invited to the annual meeting of the World War II Ranger Association. At that meeting he proposed that the association be expanded to allow all Rangers to join. This was the seed that started the National Ranger Memorial Foundation. Ranger Tucker returned to command his old battalion from Vietnam, the 1st of the 18th Infantry at Fort Riley, KS. He continued his leadership by example, always leading from the front and doing the hard right thing, never the easy wrong. Since retirement, Jim Tucker has continued to serve, in his community and assisting the Florida Ranger Camp. Ranger Tucker has lived the Ranger Creed his entire life and is an example to us all for selfless service to our nation.

Colonel Robert S. Poydasheff has provided effective, professional support of Rangers for more than fifty years. His exemplary accomplishments as an officer and his successful career in law and government at the highest levels mark him as man worthy of this distinction. He has freely shared his time and knowledge helping Rangers and Ranger organizations, preventing and solving problems in law and regulation, ranging from personal matters, to major legal and military justice issues. In landmark trials of soldiers accused of crimes, he refused to leave a fallen comrade and conducted a skillful and effective defense, gaining recognition from the Secretary of the Army for the extraordinary skill exhibited. He met the highest standards in personal and official conduct in every office and was a unifying force in his leadership as Councilman and then as Mayor, Columbus, GA. His foresight, planning, organizational skills and energy lead directly to superb cooperation between Fort Benning and Columbus in warding off loss of the 75th Ranger Regiment in the Base Realignment and Closure study, and in causing Fort Benning to make major gains in strength, facilities and missions that will benefit the Army and national security for decades to come. He assisted in the formation of the U. S. Army Ranger Association, Inc. and the National Ranger Memorial Foundation. He assisted retired Rangers in the fight against drugs in a local neighborhood. He served the Army in liaison to the Congress on a wide range of issues and the Department of Defense in the management of the Defense Dependent School System. In Berlin, assigned regular duties as a Judge Advocate, he also assisted in an intelligence operation involving a defector, taking charge of him and securing him until he could be moved to safety. A volunteer in Vietnam, he received a citation from the CIA for exemplary assistance to their operations. Colonel Bob has exemplified the Ranger Creed in thought, word and deed in supporting Rangers, Ranger families, Ranger Assns, & the Ranger Memorial Foundation.

MSG(R) Brayman served the Ranger Training Command/Ranger Department with distinction during multiple tours of duty. As a member of the Combat Conditioning Committee he demonstrated rare effectiveness and versatile ability. His exceptionally good judgment, extensive professional knowledge, devotion to duty and unselfish philosophy of service made him outstandingly effective as an Instructor in bayonet, hand-to-hand combat and physical training. As a principal Instructor, RGR Brayman exhibited the traits which characterized a successful Infantryman and an outstanding Instructor. His thorough knowledge of the subject, demonstrated ability to communicate ideas, ability to organize lesson materials, and ability to grow professionally enabled him to greatly increase the accepted standards of instruction by inspiring confidence and progress in the Ranger Student. As Chief Instructor of the Patrolling Committee, RGR Brayman influenced not only fellow instructors, but the Students that formed the backbone of our Army for years to come. As an Advisor to the 52d Vietnamese Ranger Battalion, Ranger Brayman instilled the values and attributes of the American Ranger which increased the units' success against the insurgent guerilla forces. Ranger Brayman was the epitome of a Ranger Noncommissioned Officer. Ranger Brayman's values, attributes and strength of character are evident in Ranger Training to this day.

1SG Ronald Grenier is recognized for performance, courage, and leadership in critical and sensitive positions. In 1967 he began his extraordinary career ending with 26 years of service. In 1978 1SG Grenier was assigned to his first Ranger Unit and in August of 1979 he graduated from Ranger School. This assignment helped set the foundation of him being a model Ranger that many would encounter and remember as an ideal Ranger. He was instrumental in the success of the 75th Ranger Regiment's Ranger Indoctrination Program known as "RIP" as well as their Pre-Ranger Course. He was also instrumental in helping with the formation of the newly formed 3rd Ranger Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment in Oct 1984. While assigned to C Co 4th RTB, 1SG Grenier was instrumental in helping train thousands of future Army Ranger Leaders. He certified countless new Ranger Instructors on Ranger course doctrine, techniques, and Periods of Instructions. He was also a key factor in spearheading the revision of the Army Hand to Hand demonstration techniques. He helped improve the battalion's physical health through relationship with Martin Army Community Hospital Orthopedic Physicians. He also remodeled the Ranger Gym which later came known as the "Ranger Muscle Factory" Ranger Grenier is the epitome of a Ranger.

Deputy Secretary Dennis Fowler Hightower was commissioned in the Regular Army, Infantry branch, upon graduation from Howard University in 1962. Upon graduation from Ranger School and Airborne School he was assigned to the 101st Airborne Division. In January 1965, Dennis received a branch transfer to Army Intelligence and he subsequently attended the Intelligence Officer Basic and Intelligence Research Officer Courses. Following an assignment in 1965 to the 502nd MI Bn, Republic of Korea, Dennis was a student at Ft. Holabird, MD. He then was assigned to DIA in 1967, in Washington, DC. His next assignment was the 199th LIB (SEP) (LT), RVN, where he served as the S-2 of the 4/12th Inf. Bn., Commanding Officer of the 179th MID, and the S-2 of the 199th. Upon his return to the United States, he was assigned to DA/OACSI, Army General Staff, Washington, D.C. After Dennis left the military, he accepted a managerial position with the Xerox Corporation before attending and graduating from the Harvard University Graduate School of Business. After graduating from Harvard, Dennis held management positions of increasing responsibility with several major corporations. After retirement Dennis and accepted a position as a Professor of Management at Harvard Business School, served on numerous corporate and not-for profit boards, has been a guest lecturer on leadership, and a trustee of Howard University and chairman of the Andrew Young Center for International Affairs at Morehouse College. Dennis was brought out of retirement by President Obama, and was unanimously confirmed by the United States Senate as Deputy Secretary/Chief Operating Officer US Department of Commerce. Dennis also served a member of the President's Management Council, the Transatlantic Business Dialogue with the European Union, and on special White House task forces relating to national security, foreign investment in the U.S., cyber security, and satellite acquisition (with DOD and NASA), until he resigned on August 2010.

Major Claude D. "Johnny" Johnson in many endeavors led the way before qualified as Ranger. In just two years he was Sgt. and served in Japan, Korea and Hawaii. He now qualified in Explosive Ordnance (EOD), awarded the EIB, graduated Military Mountaineering and NCO school. At four years the honor student of Basic Airborne School, 18th Airborne NCO Academy, Pathfinder School and graduated fourth in Ranger class 2-58. He won the Commandant's Inspection at the 7 Army NCO Academy. Instructor at the 101st Airborne Recondo School teaching Ranger techniques. As a Captain in the 3rd Rangers was XO of MTT that trained 82nd Airborne Battalions in Desert Environmental and Mountaineering Training also training reserve Ranger companies in Puerto Rico. For four years taught Ranger students how to survive in combat. Served in Vietnam for 42 months where he trained 3 ARVN Ranger Battalions to conduct critical combat missions. Assigned to Special Missions Advisory Group, a Top Secret unit, Cpt Johnson reconstructed and retrained the 3rd ARVN Division's reconnaissance company and conducted combat missions in NVA controlled territory. The Thai Ranger School was founded by the 46th Special Forces Company when Cpt Johnson was assistant S-3. He monitored the RTA Special Warfare Center in all combined training operations. Maj. Johnson was government contractor with the Department of State for ten years. Having a Top Secret Clearance he had daily contact with U.S. Ambassadors in six foreign countries. For 34 years displaying outstanding character and leadership. Awards: National Defense Service Medal w/OLC, Korean Service Medal, United Nations Service Medal, Armed Forces Expeditionary Medal, Expert Infantryman Badge, Good Conduct Medal (2nd Award), Vietnam Campaign Medal w/60 Device, Army Commendation Medal w/V Device & OLC, Purple Heart, Air Medal, Combat Infantryman Badge, Bronze Star Medal w/3d OLC, Vietnam Training Medal 1st Class, Vietnam Gallantry Cross With Palm, Vietnam Service Medal w/2 Silver Stars, Civil Action Honor Medal, Armed Forces Honor Medal, Vietnam Parachute Badge, Royal Thai Parachute Badge, Royal Thai Army Fourragere, Master Parachutist Badge, Expert (M-14), (M-16),(M-60), 7 Overseas Bars, Ranger Tab.

Ranger Ronald R. Leonard is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his years of dedicated service to the Nation and his embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his career and life. Ranger Leonard initially joined the USAF in 1963, but soon realized that he was destined for something more challenging. After a transfer to the Infantry and the Basic Officer's Course and Airborne training, he assumed command of his first rifle company in the 2nd AR DIV. Upon receipt of orders to Vietnam in late 1966, he attended Ranger School enroute and arrived in the 173rd ABN BDE, where he assumed command of C/2-503 PIR in time for the first Battle of Dak To in June 1967. Subsequently, he assumed command of C/4-503 PIR prior to the battle of Dak To in November 1967 where he was the ground force commander who led the final assault on Hill 875, for which he was awarded both the Distinguished Service Cross and the Purple Heart. From 1968 through 1970, Ranger Leonard, as a Committee Chief/Company Commander and then S3 of the Florida Ranger Camp, positively impacted the training and lives of a significant number of young officers and NCOs in Ranger training as they were bound for the continuing conflict in SE Asia. His maintenance of standards, insistence upon realistic training and steady demeanor set an example for all with whom he served. During a subsequent voluntary return to combat in 1971, Ranger Leonard was a District Senior Advisor and during the 1972 Spring Offensive he was involved in active patrolling with regular and local forces in Binh Dinh Province. In June of 1972 he distinguished himself by fighting his way to the District Headquarters and then directing the defense of same over a four-day fight. He was subsequently awarded the Silver Star and another Purple Heart. Ranger Leonard applied his Ranger skills yet again while in command of 1-23 IN in Korea by personally leading armed patrols into the DMZ to prove or refute North Korean operations in the DMZ. His efforts in leading from the front were able to refute what had been rumors of such actions. Ranger Leonard stands tall among his Ranger comrades. He has never failed his friends, his fellow Rangers or his Nation.

LIEUTENANT (RET) TOMMY NORRIS IS INDUCTED INTO THE RANGER HALL OF FAME FOR CONSPICUOUS GALLANTRY AND INTREPIDITY IN ACTION AT THE RISK OF HIS LIFE ABOVE AND BEYOND THE CALL OF DUTY WHILE SERVING AS A RANGER QUALIFIED SEAL ADVISOR WITH THE STRATEGIC TECHNICAL DIRECTORATE ASSISTANCE TEAM IN VIETNAM. DURING THE PERIOD 10 TO 13 APRIL 1972, LIEUTENANT NORRIS COMPLETED AN UNPRECEDENTED GROUND RESCUE OF TWO DOWNED PILOT DEEP WITHIN HEAVILY CONTROLLED ENEMY TERRITORY IN QUANG TRI PROVINCE. LIEUTENANT NORRIS, ON THE NIGHT OF 10 APRIL, LED A FIVE-MAN PATROL THROUGH 2,000 METERS OF HEAVILY CONTROLLED ENEMY TERRITORY, LOCATED ONE OF THE DOWNED PILOTS AT DAYBREAK, AND RETURNED TO THE FORWARD OPERATING BASE (FOB). ON 11 APRIL, AFTER A DEVASTATING MORTAR AND ROCKET ATTACK ON THE SMALL FOB, LIEUTENANT NORRIS LED A THREE MAN TEAM ON TWO UNSUCCESSFUL RESCUE ATTEMPTS FOR THE SECOND PILOT. ON THE AFTERNOON OF THE 12TH, A FORWARD AIR CONTROLLER LOCATED THE PILOT AND NOTIFIED LIEUTENANT NORRIS. DRESSED IN FISHERMEN DISGUISES AND USING A SAMPAN, LIEUTENANT NORRIS AND ONE VIETNAMESE TRAVELED THROUGHOUT THAT NIGHT AND FOUND THE INJURED PILOT AT DAWN. COVERING THE PILOT WITH BAMBOO AND VEGETATION, THEY BEGAN THE RETURN JOURNEY, SUCCESSFULLY EVADING A NORTH VIETNAMESE PATROL. APPROACHING THE FOB, THEY CAME UNDER HEAVY MACHINE GUN FIRE. LIEUTENANT NORRIS CALLED IN AN AIR STRIKE WHICH PROVIDED SUPPRESSION FIRE AND A SMOKE SCREEN, ALLOWING THE RESCUE PARTY TO REACH THE FOB. BY HIS OUTSTANDING DISPLAY OF DECISIVE LEADERSHIP, UNDAUNTED COURAGE, AND INTESTINAL FORTITUDE IN THE FACE OF EXTREME DANGER, LIEUTENANT NORRIS ENHANCED THE FINEST TRADITIONS OF THE ARMY RANGERS AND SET THE EXAMPLE FOR OTHERS TO FOLLOW.

1SG Michael J. Ramsey is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his immeasurable contributions to U.S. Army Rangers. 1SG Ramsey has served our Nation in uniform and the community for more than 40 years and continues to serve even today. His contributions to Rangers are legendary and he has personally inspired thousands of Rangers in their quest for excellence. As a leader he has few peers, and his pursuit of excellence to the highest Ranger standards is apparent in everything he does. A leader in combat and peacetime, 1SG Ramsey has always sought out tough and demanding duty and reserved the toughest and most dangerous tasks for himself. Equally at home on the battlefield or in the local community, his demeanor and confidence serve to inspire everyone he interacts with whether they are a Ranger or not. His Ranger career was balanced between demanding tours in the Ranger Regiment and the Ranger Training Brigade. He was an integral part of the formation of the Ranger Regiment and the transition of the Ranger Department to the Ranger Training Brigade. As the Principal Instructor, he personally oversaw the Desert Phase of Ranger School as it transitioned from Fort Bliss Texas to Dugway Proving Grounds, Utah. His combat experience and unmatched field craft made him the perfect man for the job to create the balance needed to challenge and train the Rangers of this era. Dangerous tasks in any environment, live fires, and complex parachute assaults for Ranger students required an experienced hand with extraordinary skills and judgment. Using his experience from his combat parachute assault onto Point Salinas airfield on the Island of Grenada in 1983, he was able to replicate the same intensity for Ranger students in training that would allow them to successfully conduct this type of operation numerous times in the following years. Continuing to serve the community and his fellow man, 1SG Ramsey retired from the Army in 1994 and transitioned to a career in law enforcement that spans another 20 years and continues to this day. As the Chief Deputy of the Lumpkin County Sheriff's Office in Dahlonega, Georgia, he continues to stand watch while demanding a Ranger standard of his officers in uniform.

Ranger Struecker is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame in recognition of distinguished service as a Ranger Leader and Army Chaplain within the Ranger Regiment and Ranger Training Brigade spanning over two decades of army service. Ranger Struecker earned the Bronze Star Medal with 'V' device for his courageous and lifesaving actions during Operation Gothic Serpent. His combat service within the Ranger Regiment includes Operation Just Cause, Operation Desert Storm, Operation Gothic Serpent, Operation Enduring Freedom, and Operation Iraqi Freedom. Ranger Struecker exhibited the greatest display of technical competency and physical prowess winning the Best Ranger Competition in 1996. Serving as a RIP Instructor from 1994-1997, Ranger Struecker positively impacted the Ranger Regiment by exemplifying and inculcating the Ranger ethos into the lives of thousands of Rangers. Ranger Struecker answered a higher calling by receiving his Masters of Divinity and ordination within the Southern Baptist Convention. He responded to the prophetic call of 'Here I am send me', returning to the Ranger Regiment as a chaplain during the Global War on Terror. As a Ranger chaplain, Chaplain Struecker accompanied Rangers during combat operations, fortified the souls of Rangers through pre-mission prayers and worship services, counseled Rangers through various life crises, strengthened Ranger family bonds through world class retreats, and comforted families and units when Rangers paid the ultimate price in combat by leading memorials and funerals. Chaplain Struecker continues to avail himself to the Ranger and Fort Benning community as the pastor of Calvary Baptist Church. His love for Rangers is evidenced in repeated speaking engagements on Fort Benning, supporting Columbus' Mogadishu Mile, and faithfully pastoring Ranger and Fort Benning families that attend Calvary Baptist Church. Chaplain Struecker's demonstrated Ranger competency and ethos, exemplary character, and pastoral service have inspired and impacted thousands of Rangers and their families making him a worthy candidate of the Ranger Hall of Fame. RANGERS LEAD THE WAY!

Sergeant Major John W. Roy is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career.
During SGM John Roy's career, he strove to live up to the high standards he saw reflected in the outstanding soldiers with whom he served. In the parlance of the time, John was a STRAC troop. Everyone called him "Ranger Roy" out of respect for his dedication to being a top soldier. John joined the Army because he admired his older brother who was a paratrooper with the 82nd ABN in WWII and made two combat jumps into Normandy and Belgium. John began his career just when the modern day Rangers and Special Forces began and served with both units as a sol-dier and an instructor. He also helped to pioneer early Military Free Fall doctrine. As a Ranger in-structor, he met and trained many of the soldiers who went on to become great leaders in their ca-reers. John counts many of them as personal friends. He instructed and fought behind the lines in Korea, Laos, and Vietnam. John avoided the limelight and gave credit freely to others. Coming from a humble background, John appreciated the value of education and put his knowledge to use as an instructor. He always said that knowledge was a key to survival as a soldier. Hard work and a sense of humor have always been his hallmarks. If John knew a subject, he knew it completely. The importance of details in planning and endurance that he learned as a Ranger early in his ca-reer, became the way he conducted himself as a soldier.
John cares about people and has a tremendous memory for names and places. If he met you once, he would remember you in detail years later. If John were your friend, you could always count on him to help you. If John didn't know you, but you needed help, he would be the first to hold out his hand in friendship. John represents the best that America produces.
John joined the Army to become a paratrooper, but it was his training as a Ranger that made him into the outstanding soldier he became.

Command Sergeant Major Martin R. Barreras is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. CSM Martin R. "Gunny" Barreras served in the United States Marine Corps and Army from the age of 18 until succumbing to wounds sustained in combat in Afghanistan on May 13, 2014. Over the course of three decades of service in the 75th Ranger Regiment, he held every leadership position from Rifle Team Leader to Command Sergeant Major in the 1st and 2nd Ranger Battalions, the Regimental Training and Reconnaissance Company, and the Regimental Headquarters. CSM Barreras served in multiple conflicts to include Beirut, Operation Just Cause in Panama, Operation Uphold Democracy in Haiti, Operation Iraqi Freedom in Iraq, and Operation Enduring Freedom in Afghanistan where he ultimately gave his life in service to the United States of America. His awards and decorations include the Legion of Merit with one Oak Leaf Cluster, Bronze Star with V Device and three Oak Leaf Clusters, Purple Heart with two Oak Leaf Clusters, Meritorious Service Medal with two Oak Leaf Clusters, Joint Service Commendation Medal with one Oak Leaf Cluster, Army Commendation Medal with three Oak Leaf Clusters, Joint Service Achievement Medal with one Oak Leaf Cluster, Army Achievement Medal, Army Good Conduct Medal with Silver Two Knot Device, Marine Corps Good Conduct Medal, National Defense Service Medal with Bronze Service Star, Armed Forces Expeditionary Medal with Arrowhead Device and Bronze Service Star, Afghanistan Campaign Medal with three Bronze Service Stars, Iraq Campaign Medal with two Bronze Service Stars, Global War on Terrorism Expeditionary Medal, Global War on Terrorism Service Medal, Humanitarian Service Medal with two Bronze Service Stars, NCO Professional Development Ribbon with Numeral 4, Army Service Ribbon, Overseas Service Ribbon with Numeral 3, Army Meritorious Unit Citation, Navy Meritorious Unit Commendation, NATO International Security Assistance Force Medal, Combat Infantryman Badge (2nd Award), Expert Infantryman Badge, Master Parachutist Badge with Combat Jump Device, Pathfinder Badge, and Military Freefall Badge. CSM Barreras' service to the 75th Ranger Regiment, the U.S. Army Special Operations Command and the U.S. Army exemplifies the Ranger Creed and serves as an example for all.

Command Sergeant Major Robert "Bob" Gallagher is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. Command Sergeant Major Robert Gallagher's service career began in 1981 when he entered the Army an infantryman at Fort Benning, Georgia. He served his country for over 30 years before retiring in 2013. He fought bravely, risking his life when he parachuted into Panama during Operation Just Cause in 1989 with A Company, 3D Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment. He served as a Platoon Sergeant in B Company, 3rd Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment with Task Force Ranger in Mogadishu, Somalia, in a battle in which he and many of the Rangers in his platoon were wounded. CSM Gallagher fought in Iraq as well during Operation Iraqi Freedom, where he was with Task Force 3-15 Infantry when they fought their way from Kuwait to Baghdad. During his career he was awarded two Purple Hearts, two Bronze Stars (one with "V" device), and a Silver Star. In 2009, he joined the Wounded Warrior Project at Fort Belvoir, Virginia, as the Command Ser-geant Major. In this role he was able to guide Soldiers during a very difficult time in their lives. CSM Robert Gallagher cared about Soldiers. CSM Gallagher retired from the service in 2013. He left a lasting impression on all those he encountered. In retirement, he had plans of setting up a Team River Runner Branch in Savannah, Georgia to offer Kayaking trips to wounded warriors and other military families. Unfortunately, a year after his retirement CSM Robert Gallagher passed away of natural causes. During his lifetime, he displayed the true characteristics of an Army Ranger. CSM Gallagher embodied the Ranger Creed. Command Sergeant Major Robert Gallagher left a legacy that should not be forgotten, his accomplishments live on through those whom he served with and loved throughout his lifetime.

Major (Ret) Thomas Greer is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. Major Thomas Greer retired in January 2005 after more than twenty years in the U.S. Army. He served fifteen years in special operations units, as both a noncommissioned and commissioned officer. Most notably as an instructor at the U.S. Army Ranger School, eight years in the 75th Ranger Regiment, and six years as an operational commander and operations officer in an Army Special Missions Unit. Tom spent 32 months in three separate hostile fire zones and was twice decorated for valor for combat actions in Afghanistan. He hunted and apprehended war criminals in the Balkans, was the assault force commander on numerous direct action raids against Al Qaeda and Taliban personalities in Afghanistan, including targeting Usama Bin Laden, and participated in the hunt for Abu Musab alZarqawi in Iraq. In all three hot spots, Tom operated with intelligence analysts and operatives from the US Intelligence Community and worked extensively with foreign allied special operations forces and all components of USSOF during Operation Enduring Freedom and Operation Iraqi Freedom.

Master Sergeant Clifford Manning is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. MSG Clifford Manning is inducted into the U.S. Army Ranger Hall of Fame in recognition of selfless service to the United States of America during both combat in Korea and Vietnam, and in time of military preparedness in a noncombative role. MSG Manning's highly skilled, effective leadership as a MACV Military Advisor, saved the lives of many Soldiers with whom he served and reflects why he was awarded two Silver Stars. His second Silver Star was presented by General William Westmoreland for combat valor. During that encounter with the enemy, then Sergeant Manning put himself in harm's way when another American Advisor was seriously wounded. Manning moved the injured soldier across 20 meters of open terrain to a place of safety and, after administering immediate first aid, requested the assistance of a medical evacuation helicopter. As it landed it was heavily damaged by communist fire and unable to take off. Sergeant Manning provided a base of fire. He was able to pin down the enemy until a safe evacuation was organized. During MSG Manning's second tour in Vietnam, he served as First Sergeant of Company G (Ranger) 75th Infantry and was without exception respected by every Ranger and LRRP he led. His leadership, sharing "lessons learned" from Korea and as a MACV Advisor earned him the Award of the Army Commendation Medal, Second Oak Leaf Cluster. MSG Manning also served as First Sergeant of the 1st Ranger Company at the Ranger Training School Brigade at Elgin AFB, Florida, where he continued as a professional. He was a role model, exemplifying the Ranger Creed to those that strived to become a Ranger. MSG Manning earned and gave respect to his peers and candidates at all times, never wavering. He, thus, was awarded the Army Commendation Medal, Third Oak Leaf Cluster. MSG Manning is a lifetime member of Company G Ranger 75th Infantry and longtime member of the 75th Ranger Regiment Association. He has volunteered on his own time taking ROTC Army Cadets from Georgia Tech on weekend trips to Fort Benning for training.

Colonel John J Ellis is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. Colonel Ellis is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his distinguished service to the Ranger and Special Operations communities and our Nation for 30 Years. Ranger Ellis repeatedly volunteered for Ranger assignments. He commanded an Infantry company in Vietnam and another at Fort Hood, Texas. He subsequently commanded two Ranger Companies with distinction: Company A (LRRP), 75th Infantry (Ranger), and Company B, 1st Battalion (Ranger), 75th Infantry. Ranger Ellis was selected as the first Ranger Operations Officer, Joint Special Operations Command, where he planned and supervised the execution of numerous highly classified operations involving Rangers and other special mission units. Selected to command 2d Ranger Battalion following the relief of the previous commander, Ranger Ellis focused the battalion to meet pressing, real world operational requirements. His dynamic from the front leadership style revitalized the battalion and rekindled the Ranger spirit. His unrelenting focus on METL driven, realistic training, firmly rooted in the execution of sound basics, Ranger discipline and initiative, had a profound, immediate impact on the battalion. He lived the Ranger Creed in both word and deed and his example was the standard for every Ranger in the battalion. His personal leadership and total dedication to the mission and his Rangers ensured the battalion was always combat ready and could deploy, fight and win. He is the longest serving commander in 2d Ranger Battalion history. Ranger Ellis subsequently served with distinction in a number of key assignments to include G-3, 2d Infantry Division; Commander, 9th Infantry Regiment (Manchu) 7th ID; Director of Combating Terrorism, Office of Secretary of Defense; and as Deputy Section Chief, Domestic Terrorism Unit, FBI,

Major Michael R. Wagers is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. As a 19-year old Staff Sergeant, MAJ Wagers served as a Squad Leader Platoon Sergeant and Platoon Leader of a Rifle Platoon in Vietnam. Of particular significance, the entire year he was leading his platoon, there was only one member who did not return from Vietnam alive. He earned his Ranger Tab in Ranger Class 13-71, and was always eager to hone his skills. The Provo, Utah native went on to complete Pathfinder School, Jumpmaster School, 3rd Army Chemical-Biological-Radiological Warfare School, 3rd Army Noncommissioned Officer Academy, and was also selected to attend The Canadian Winter Warfare Instructor Course. He was assigned as a Rifle Platoon Sergeant with Company C (Rangers), 1st Battalion, 29th Infantry and a year later was to be the youngest of the original nine Rifle Platoon Sergeants for the newly formed 1st Ranger Battalion, 75th Infantry. In 1980, after only thirteen years' service, First Sergeant Wagers made a career status change; he received an Honorable Discharge with a concurrent call to active duty (Direct Commission) as a First Lieutenant, Infantry, assigned to the 21st Infantry, 25th Infantry Division. In 1984, after the activation of the 75th Ranger Regiment, General Wayne A. Downing, having first-hand knowledge of Major Wagers abilities as a leader and trainer, asked Major Wagers to serve as the first Commander of the Ranger Indoctrination (RIP) Detachment, 75th Ranger Regiment, this marking his third consecutive command and his fourth Ranger assignment. Most recently, he has continued to share his knowledge gleaned throughout his career while traveling to Saudi Arabia and the Middle East, where he lived and worked as a consultant for a total of eighteen years. He now resides with his wife in Tennessee and is active with other Rangers of Middle Tennessee and enjoys spending time with, and mentoring and life coaching, young Rangers and other veterans.

Colonel Ronald R. Leonard is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. Ranger Leonard initially joined the USAF in 1963, but soon realized that he was destined for something more challenging. After a transfer to the Infantry and the Basic Officer's Course and Airborne training, he assumed command of his first rifle company in the 2nd Armored Division. Upon receipt of orders to Vietnam in late 1966, he attended Ranger School enroute and arrived in the 173rd Airborne Brigade, where he commanded C/2-503 Infantry in the first Battle of Dak To in June 1967. Subsequently, he commanded B/4-503 Infantry during a subsequent battle of Dak To in November 1967 where he was the ground force commander who led the final assault on Hill 875, for which he was awarded both the Distinguished Service Cross and the Purple Heart. From 1968 through 1970, Ranger Leonard, as a Committee Chief/Company Commander and then S3 of the Florida Ranger Camp, positively impacted the training and lives of a significant number of young officers and NCOs in Ranger training as they were bound for the continuing conflict in SE Asia. He lived and operated by a Ranger Creed not yet developed. His maintenance of standards, insistence upon realistic training and steady demeanor set an example for all with whom he served. During a subsequent voluntary return to combat in 1971, Ranger Leonard was a District Senior Advisor uring the 1972 Spring Offensive and was involved in active patrolling with regular and local forces in Binh Dinh Province. In June of 1972 he distinguished himself by fighting his way to the District Headquarters and then directing the defense of same over a four-day fight. He was subsequently awarded the Silver Star and another Purple Heart. Ranger Leonard applied his Ranger skills yet again while in command of 1-23 Infantry in Korea by personally leading armed patrols into the DMZ to prove or refute North Korean operations in the DMZ. His efforts in leading from the front were able to refute what had been rumors of such actions. Ranger Leonard stands tall among his Ranger comrades, never taking the easy path. He has never failed his friends, his fellow Rangers, the Ranger Creed or his Nation.

Captain Fred O. Jackson Jr. is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. Ranger Jackson was recognized more than once for gallantry and intrepidity in action at the risk of his own life above and beyond the call of duty. During his second tour of combat in the Republic of Vietnam, he gave his life fulfilling the Ranger Creed while providing aerial gun support for a small Recon Unit in heavy contact with a superior sized force. His Cobra was crippled by enemy small arms fire. Exemplifying the Ranger Creed, he refused to leave the Recon Team on the ground until he had expended all his ammunition. He then flew back to the airfield and exchanged his bird for a healthy one. He immediately returned to the battle and again began engaging the enemy. This time his Cobra was raked by heavy machine gun fire from a gun that had been moved into support the enemy in the fight. Ranger Jackson's wingman advised him his Cobra was on fire, however, Ranger Jackson refused to leave the battle until all of his ordinance was expended. Ranger Jackson's last words are an example of his Warrior Mindset and Determination to live the Ranger Creed; "I'm going to fire up the enemy, then I'll go get another aircraft and return." Shortly thereafter, his Cobra exploded, instantly killing him on 5 September 1969. During his first tour of combat he led a Rifle Platoon for six months. He then volunteered to serve as the Operations Officer for the 1st Infantry Division Long Range Reconnaissance Patrol (LRRP) Platoon, displaying the "Rangers Lead The Way" attitude. Ranger Jackson did not assign someone else to take out the most dangerous patrols rather, he led eight highly successful Recon Missions deep in enemy held territory. Ranger Jackson was the epitome of an Army Ranger, leading from the front, fighting to the objective and never leaving a fallen comrade behind .

LTC David Prybyla is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. An honor graduate of Infantry OCS IN 1967, he became Airborne qualified and volunteered for service in Vietnam. Assigned to A Company, 1/503 Infantry, 173rd Airborne Brigade he served as a platoon leader, executive officer and company commander. During this tour he was awarded his first Bronze Star Medal and Purple Heart. He completed Ranger training as an honor graduate in 1970 and was assigned to the Ranger Department where he was an instructor for Patrolling Committee, Benning Ranger Committee and company tactical officer. In 1971 he returned to Viet Nam and was assigned to Division Combat Assistance Team (DCAT) 87 as a Senior Battalion Advisor. Ranger Prybyla's tour of duty was shortened by being critically wounded on 27 April 1972 during the Easter Offensive. During this tour, Ranger Prybyla was awarded two Silver Stars, two Bronze Star Medals with "V" Device and second Purple Heart. After being evacuated from theater and following nearly a year of hospitalization and rehabilitation he returned to duty for another 12 years, ultimately being medically retired due to his combat wounds. Ranger Prybyla has lived a life exemplifying the best of the Ranger traditions. Courage, dedication and determination have been his foremost traits. As his multiple separate awards attest, he has demonstrated the rare characteristic of "sustained" valor. Ranger Prybyla's contributions throughout his military and civilian career are in keeping with the highest traditions of service and reflect the utmost credit upon himself, the United States Army and the entire Ranger community.

Mr. Jean-Marc Lefranc is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for more than 30 years of dedicated and sustained support to generations of Rangers. Mr. Lefranc has been an ardent supporter of Rangers as a private citizen and while serving in a number of important elected positions to include mayor of Grandcamp-Maisy and the French Parliament. A life-long resident of Normandy, he met World War II Ranger veterans at the D-Day, 40th Anniversary. He resolved then to ensure the people of Normandy always remembered the sacrifices of the Rangers who fought and died there to restore peace, freedom and democracy. As the mayor of Grandcamp-Maisy, he led the community supporting returning Rangers and their families. He organized ceremonies, services, and other commemorative events, often providing transportation, meals and lodging at no cost. On many occasions he hosted returning veterans and their families at his home. In 1989, Mr. Lefranc attended a World War II Ranger reunion. Solely on his own initiative, he promised to create a museum to tell the Ranger story. On 6 June, 1990, he fulfilled his promise when Le Musée des Rangers was opened. He raised the necessary funds, personally obtained much of the memorabilia and authored significant portions of the written exhibits. Later, again on his own initiative, he established a Ranger Memorial in Grandcamp-Maisy, dedicated to coincide with the 55th D-Day Anniversary. He was the key French proponent for the restoration and the preservation of Pointe du Hoc. Working with numerous French agencies, he obtained the funds to restore the site. The renovation included observation platforms, walking paths, a ceremonial area, a parking lot to accommodate the huge visitor load and a visitor center to welcome people. When the observation bunker was closed to the public in 2001 due to significant erosion of the cliff face that jeopardize the structural integrity of the bunker, he pushed through the bureaucracy to obtain the authorization for the work. Due to his persistent efforts, the bunker was reopened to the public and once again is the centerpiece of the visitor experience at Pointe du Hoc. Mr. Lefranc continues his unwavering support for Rangers in his current role as President, D-Day Commemoration Committee.

Master Sergeant Retired Joey Alan Carpenter is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. Ranger Carpenter served in the United States Army for 26 years. He served in numerous Ranger units in various positions. He continuously demonstrated his bravery and dedication as he served throughout the United States of America and outside the country in Grenada, Panama, Iraq, Somalia, Haiti, Bosnia, and Afghanistan. During his time as the Exchange Non-Commissioned Officer in Australia, Ranger Carpenter served as an ambassador to junior officers and NCOs of the Australian Army. Throughout his long career, he received many awards for his hard work and service. These awards include the Legion of Merit, Defense Meritorious Service Medal (2nd Award), three Joint Civilian Service Achievement Awards, two Superior Civilian Service Awards, three Commander's Awards for Civilian Service, and a Combat Action Ribbon. He also received the Master Parachutist Badge with two Combat Jump Stars, the Bronze German Armed Forces Parachute Badge, the Royal Australian Army Parachute Badge, and the Canadian Parachutist Badge. Carpenter was aware of the importance of his role as a soldier and even more importantly his duty as a ranger. His talents helped encourage those below him to emulate the utmost respect for duty and responsibility. Ranger Carpenter continues to exemplify every aspect of the ranger creed.

Colonel Garry E. Curtis is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. Ranger Garry E. Curtis has always led the way by setting the proper example among his fellows in war and during peacetime. He led the way during his two successful assignments with 2nd Ranger Company at Camp Frank D. Merrill, first as an instructor in the Patrolling Division and later in the Mountaineering Division. Always serving with distinction, Ranger Curtis led the way during his combat tours first in the Dominican Republic with 1/508th PIR and later in the Republic of South Vietnam with 5th Special Forces Group. Ranger Curtis continually demonstrated his keen ability to analyze, plan, and execute his operational assignments both in war and during peacetime. During his six years with Delta Force, Ranger Curtis served as an operations NCO successfully planning and coordinating support activities with joint staffs, foreign units, and selected US Government and Civilian Agencies. As an ROTC advisor and mentor, he guided his Tennes-see Tech University ROTC students ("Tech Rangers") to finishing in first place in three consecutive state competitions and second place overall at the U.S. Military Endurance Sports (Region 2) 1988 Ranger Challenge. Indeed, throughout his entire military career, Ranger Curtis has continually demonstrated the highest ideals of military excellence. With each assignment, he has taken every opportunity to demonstrate his commitment to service in the Ranger tradition. Ranger Curtis is a trusted leader and warrior admired by all who have served with him. In retirement, Ranger Curtis continued serving the Ranger community as a member of the US Mountain Ranger Association. He is active in his faith community and never misses an opportunity to help those in need. Ranger Curtis' lifetime of leadership has contributed tremendously to the Ranger community, the profession of arms, and to fostering Ranger ideals wherever he served.

Colonel Paris Davis is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. On 19 June 1965, then Captain Davis distinguished himself by exceptionally valorous action while serving as a U.S Army Special Forces Advisor near Bong Son, Republic of Vietnam. While returning from a successful raid on a Viet Cong position, the 883rd Regional Forces Company, the company advised by Captain Davis, was ambushed, and sustained several casualties. Captain Davis, constantly exposing himself to hostile small arms fire, rallied the disorganized unit and directed artillery and small arms fire, which enabled other elements to reach his position. Although wounded in the leg, he aided in the evacuation of other wounded men of his unit. Following arrival of air support, Captain Davis, with complete disregard for his own personal safety, directed artillery fire within 30 meters of his own position enabling him to reach his seriously wounded Team Sergeant. While carrying the Sergeant up a hill, Captain Davis was again wounded. Despite his two painful wounds, he remained with the troops while they repelled several Viet Cong assaults of his position. When a relief force arrived, Captain Davis refused medical evacuation until all other wounded had been evacuated. For his actions, Captain Davis, was awarded the Silver Star and recommended for the Medal of Honor.

CW3 Ronald Johnson is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. Ranger Johnson is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his outstanding service as a Ranger throughout his military career. His aggressive and tireless efforts of service, coupled with a wholehearted devotion to duty, serve as an example for all Rangers. Ranger Johnson lived his life according to the Ranger Creed. He always set the example as a leader in Ranger Units. Though wounded in action during Operation Urgent Fury, he overcame the adversity never failing to be out front and serving as an example for all his fellow Rangers. Ranger Johnson mentored and coached many young Ranger students while a Ranger instructor in the Florida Ranger camp. His influence motivated many young Rangers to higher levels of performance resulting in their receiving the coveted Ranger Tab. His established record of profound service as a Ranger continued as an Army Aviator. He flew combat missions including insertion and extraction missions behind enemy lines in support of LongRange Surveillance Detachment Teams during Operation Desert Storm. Later continuing in the Ranger tradition, Ranger Johnson was selected and served with 160th Special Operation Aviation Regiment flying in support of Special Operations around the world. Ranger Johnson's service continued in retirement flying in support of the United States Department of State. He gave his life piloting a MH-6 while providing close support during combat operations in Baghdad against anti Iraqi forces. Ron exemplified the Ranger spirit all the way to his last breath. From Grenada to Baghdad, in peacetime and war, CW3 Johnson served his country as a Soldier and a Ranger.

Lieutenant Colonel Retired J.D. Kirby is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. Lieutenant Colonel J.D. Kirby has led the way conspicuously throughout his military and civilian careers. He led the way during two assignments at Camp Frank D. Merrill. In, 1968, he was repeatedly selected as a principal instructor, the best of the best, during the centralized training era when leadership opportunities were limited. He led the way as Tactical Officer of Ranger Class 270, providing an outstanding example of leadership and motivation. From October 1984 to May 1987, as commander of Camp Merrill, Ranger Kirby was directly responsible for both the Mountain and Desert phases of Ranger School. He accomplished the overlapping missions without additional resources. He led the way on 14 major deployments annually into the desert training sites. He was the Airborne Commander in might parachute insertions and senior Fort Benning representative on the ground. Ranger Kirby conducted the test cycle of Dugway Proving Ground, UT resulting in its selection. He lived and let the Mtn Ranger Division by the code of "leadership by example" for 31 months during a period of significant mission change, permanent construction initiatives, and reorganization of training for a centralized to decentralized concept. Ranger Kirby led the way during two 12-month combat tours in Vietnam. He served with distinction as a rifle Platoon Leader, Company XO, Company Commander and Brigade Staff Officer. As company XO, he assumed temporary command of a sister company when its commander was wounded in action. "He steadied the company and successfully directed it in thwarting an enemy attack." For his service in Vietnam, he 4 Bronze Stars, 2 Purple Hearts, the Air Medal, and an Army Commendation Medal with 'V' Device. In retirement, he continued to lead the way in service in the Ranger Community. He was responsible for the planning, fundraising, installing and dedication of three monuments at Arnold AFB, Pine Valley (University of North Georgia) and Camp Merrill memorializing and honoring the service of his Ranger brothers. Always at ease in situations characterized by uncertainty, Ranger Kirby's lifeline of leadership has contributed tremendously to the Rangers, the profession of arms, and the enhancement of the Ranger image in the eyes of his countrymen.

Sergeant Major Retired Alfred J. Lamb is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. SGM (Ret) Alfred J. Lamb is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his extraordinary dedication, commitment, and contributions to the 75th Ranger Regiment. He served in two of the three Ranger Battalions, some multiple times to include the Regimental HQs in his 23 years of service as a Ranger leader. Ranger Lamb entered the Army in June 1981. He volunteered to serve in the Ranger Regiment and was assigned to B Co 2nd BN (RGR), 75th INF serving as a machine gunner and participated in the assault on the island of Grenada as part of "Operation Urgent Fury." Ranger Lamb volunteered, and is a plank member of the 3rd Ranger Battalion, where he served as TM LDR/SQD LDR during the BN's validation process. He then moved to the Regimental HQ's and served as a Pre-Ranger instructor ensuring hundreds of Ranger candidates were prepared to graduate from Ranger School. He then served in a Ranger position in B Co, 2nd BN, 1st SWTG (A) as a military free fall instructor; he was then assigned to B Co, 3rd RGR BN as the WPNS PSG and deployed in support of TF Ranger for OPS in Somalia. During this deployment he was awarded the Silver Star Medal following the crash of Blackhawk helicopter in the streets of Mogadishu, "He ignored the deadly fire of a numerically superior enemy force to overrun the embattled survivors of the crash, he roped down into the tenuous defensive perimeter in efforts to rescue the American survivors". In addition, the majority of his Platoon was awarded the Bronze Star Medal with V Devices for their actions. Ranger Lamb's willingness to Lead the Way and live the Ranger Creed reflects great credit upon himself, the Ranger Community, and The United States Army

Sergeant Major William L. Lubbers is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. Sergeant Major William L. Lubbers is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for extraordinary courage and heroism while serving under 3rd Special Forces Group (Airborne). On 15 November 2012, Sergeant Major Lubbers distinguished himself by disregarding his personal safety in order to save numerous civilians during a Veteran's Day Parade in Midland, TX. During the event, a parade float carrying wounded veterans and their spouses was struck by a train moving 60 miles per hour. Sergeant Major Lubbers showed remarkable bravery, courage and selfless actions when he jumped up from his seat and began to physically move people to get them to the ground with absolutely no regard for his own personal safety. He remained on the float helping others until the train made impact, saving the lives of several other veterans and their wives. Through his courageous actions, Sergeant Major Lubbers made the ultimate sacrifice. Sergeant Major Lubbers' awards included three Bronze Star Medals, a Purple Heart, the Combat Infantry Badge, the Expert Infantry Badge, the Special Forces Tab, multiple Campaign, and Service Medals, and was posthumously awarded The Legion of Merit and the Soldier's Medal. Sergeant Major Lubbers' actions are in keeping with the finest traditions of military heroism and reflect distinct credit upon himself, the United States Army Rangers, 3rd Special Forces Group (Airborne), and the United States Army.

Command Sergeant Major Arthur J. McCann III is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. Ranger Arthur J. McCann III is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame in recognition of his career of devoted, inspiring, and selfless service. Throughout his 27 ½ years as a Soldier boldly leading the way in assignments and missions as a leader with the 1st Ranger Battalion, the 5th Ranger Training Battalion, the 25th Infantry Division , the 173rd Airborne Brigade, and in First Army, he established exemplary standards shaping his legacy as a model for his peers. He sought every opportunity to further develop himself as a professional Soldier, accepting all challenges in the mold of the ideal Airborne Ranger. He carried the lessons he learned along the way to share with his subordinates as an inspiration to all with whom he served. A confident leader of flawless determination, resolve, and integrity, Ranger McCann continually demonstrated the ideals of the Ranger Creed through every assignment and mission, to include combat operations during Operation Just Cause with 1st Ranger Battalion, and multiple missions during Operation Iraqi Freedom, and Enduring Freedom in Afghanistan, with 173rd Airborne Brigade. He was always out front on patrols with Soldiers. While conducting operations in Afghanistan he was awarded the Purple Heart. Though there are many instances of his belief in and application of the Ranger Creed, perhaps, the most significant is having been awarded the Soldier's Medal for Heroism rescuing a Soldier from a downed aircraft at the risk of his own life. Upon retirement, Ranger McCann was awarded the Legion of Merit for his outstanding service to his country. Dedicated to his country, his family, and his community, Ranger McCann continues to serve in the Ranger tradition. Coaching high school wrestling, advising students, and participating in Veterans affairs are but a few examples. A devoted husband, inspiring father, and a trusted school administrator and coach, Ranger McCann always has and continues to "lead the way."

Honorable Ryan D. McCarthy is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military and professional career. Honorable Ryan D. McCarthy is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his exceptional commitment to the U.S. Army and this Nation while demonstrating and achieving excellence and unparalleled commitment to the Ranger Way. He is a combat veteran from Operation Enduring Freedom in 2001-2002 with 3d Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment. During his service, Hon. McCarthy received the Joint Service Commendation Medal and Combat Infantryman Badge. Hon. McCarthy's foundation with the Ranger Creed and Ranger Regiment set him on a pathway for continued government service. In December 2006, Hon. McCarthy joined Secretary of Defense Robert Gates' transition team, and in April 2007 became the special assistant to Secretary Gates until June 2011, serving under appointment in both the President Bush and Obama administrations. While in position, he tirelessly worked to shape and implement Department of Defense policy on behalf of Secretary Gates through two troop surges, one in Operation Iraqi Freedom, and one in Operation Enduring Freedom, while navigating a very difficult fiscal environment. Hon. McCarthy returned to government service as the Under Secretary of the Army starting August 1, 2017, where he initially served as the Acting Secretary of the Army for four months. During his tenure, he championed the Army's effort to modernize and increase efficiency as the chief management officer for the Army. Hon. McCarthy drove the Army's largest organizational change since 1973 with the establishment of Army Futures Command, which brings the entire modernization enterprise under one command with a focused investment strategy. He accomplished that by restructuring the modernization budget in science and technology, research and development, and procurement. Hon. McCarthy also led Army efforts to reorganize and refocus the Army recruiting enterprise to ensure the officers and enlisted ranks represent the country's population without sacrificing talent and in budget management to build the Army our Nation needs to meet the demands of the future. Hon McCarthy is the embodiment of the Ranger.

COL Robert Reitz is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military and professional career. Ranger Reitz is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his distinguished service devoting 27 years serving in Ranger, Special Forces, and Infantry units. Serving as a Company commander with the 1st BN, 17th Infantry, Ranger Reitz was credited with successfully blocking a North Korean infiltration attempt against a Nike Missile site south of camp Kaiser, ROK. He served two combat tours in Vietnam, first as Senior Advisor to the 35th Vietnamese Ranger BN (Biet Dong Quan), deployed to the Cholon district of Saigon during the 1968 TET Offensive. His second tour 1970-71 assigned as S/2 1st BN, 1st Cavalry, 1st BDE, 1st Cav Division first in Cambodia then in WAR Zone D, Vietnam. During his tours Ranger Reitz was awarded the Silver Star, three Bronze Stars, and a Purple Heart and fought in six major campaigns. As the Brigade intelligence officer, he was successful in locating and stopping enemy forces trying to maneuver around 1st BN, 7th Cav. Later as S/3 he successfully led plans and operations against enemy forces. Ranger Reitz completed the Command and General Staff College was given the responsibility as Battalion Commander to activate and train 1st BN, 122nd Infantry within 5 years. He successfully completed this mission in 2 years resulting in the Battalion being selected as best in the 1st Army. Since retirement Ranger Reitz has been extremely active in Ranger and Veterans organizations such as US Army Ranger Association, 75th Ranger Regiment Association Ranger Advisors to the Biet Dong Quana, VFW, Purple Heart Assoc, DAV, founding member Vietnam Veterans Alliance, and is the Service Officer for American Legion Post 149. He has assisted over 100 veterans in obtaining benefits and medical help. He also sponsored his Vietnamese counterpart and family he remains a "trusted friend," and attends many of their family functions. Ranger Reitz makes personal visits with veterans in nursing homes to honor their service to America.

Master Sergeant (Ret) Eric Stebner served 15 of 20 years (1995-2015) of his US Army Ranger active service in Special Operations Units with distinction. While assigned to 1st Ranger Battalion, MSG Stebner completed ten combat deployments supporting the Global War on Terrorism. He completed four combat tours in support of Operation Enduring Freedom and six combat tours in support of Operation Iraqi Freedom over a period of seven years. MSG Stebner served in an extensive range of duty and leadership positions, including Rifleman, Team Leader, Sniper, Sniper Team Leader, Squad Leader, Sniper Section Leader, Headquarters' Platoon Sergeant, Sniper Platoon Sergeant, and Rifle Platoon Sergeant. He was the only Rifle Platoon Sergeant in a Joint Special Operations Task Force that operated independently from the Company during Operation Iraqi Freedom. He served as the JSOC LNO to SOCEUR (2009) for a five-month period while assigned to the 75th Ranger Regiment Headquarters. MSG Stebner was a NATO Special Operations Instructor (2010-2013) throughout Western Europe serving in a Special Forces Billet. During his combat deployments, MSG Stebner conducted more than 650 direct action raids and was responsible for the kill or capture of nearly 450 coalition forces and dozens of high value targets. While training Rangers and in combat, MSG Stebner ensured he always brought every Ranger home safely. MSG Stebner was exceptional in his actions during the 17-hour Battle of Robert's Ridge [Battle of Takur Ghar] supporting Operation Anaconda. On March 4, 2002, he was part of a 20-man Quick Reaction Force called to rescue a Navy SEAL in the snowy mountains of Afghanistan. MSG Stebner was the Alpha Fire Team Leader of his 10-man Chalk. He led the treacherous climb up the 70-degree mountain slope at elevations ranging from 7,900-10,500 feet. MSG Stebner then organized an assault against enemy-fortified positions. For four hours, he led all aid and litter teams under withering enemy counterattack fire during casualty consolidation. During that period of the firefight, MSG Stebner exposed himself to enemy fire at least five times to save his fellow Rangers. Seven American soldiers lost their lives in that battle. For his valorous actions that day, MSG Stebner was awarded the Silver Star.

Command Sergeant Major Retired Dennis Smith is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military and professional career. CSM(R) Dennis L. Smith entered the Army in February 1986 as an Infantryman and culminated his 26 1/2 year career as the Ranger Training Brigade Command Sergeant Major. After retirement, he continued to serve the Ranger community as the owner of Uncommon Athlete, a physical fitness facility with a focus on preparing men and women for the rigors of Ranger School and RAP week. He also is the Cofounder of Darby's Warrior Support, an Arkansas-based nonprofit that provides post-9/11 combat veterans with all-inclusive hunting and fishing opportunities in a wholesome environment to foster rehabilitation, recovery, and transition. CSM(R) Smith served in numerous Infantry, Pathfinder, and Ranger assignments, to include leadership positions at the Squad, Platoon, Company, and Battalion level in the 75th Ranger Regiment and at the Brigade level for the Ranger Training Brigade. Ranger Smith has served the Ranger community as a Squad Leader, Platoon Sergeant, First Sergeant, Operations Sergeant Major, and Command Sergeant Major in 1st Battalion, 3d Battalion, and the Regimental Special Troops Battalion of the 75th Ranger Regiment. CSM(R) Smith deployed to combat in support of Operations Desert Shield/Storm and 11 times to Iraq and Afghanistan in support of the Global War on Terror. He led a parachute assault into Western Iraq in March 2003. He earned the Purple Heart and was awarded four Bronze Stars in recognition of his combat leadership. Always a Ranger at heart, CSM(R) Dennis L. Smith strives to live the Ranger Creed every day and epitomizes the high standards of the Ranger Regiment.

Marauder (Technician Fifth Grade) Russell G. Wellman is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military and professional career. Marauder (Technician Fifth Grade) Russell G. Wellman is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his heroic and exemplary conduct in action against the armed enemy in the China Burma India Theater of Operations as a member of the 5307th Composite Unit (Provisional) (Merrill's Marauders). On 28 July 1944, during the battle to capture the town of Myitkyina, Burma, T/5 Wellman rescued a wounded fellow Marauder who was pinned down by intense heavy machine gun and small arms fire. Moving forward under the intense machine gun and small arms fire, T/5 Wellman suffered bullet wounds to his abdominal area and more than 20 shrapnel wounds to his back as he rescued his fellow Marauder. Though seriously ill with malaria and amoebic dysentery plus his combat wounds, he remained with the Marauders until the town of Myitkyina was captured on 3 August and the Marauders disbanded on 10 August. T/5 Wellman was evacuated to the United States in September 1944. For his heroic actions at the town of Myitkyina, T/5 Wellman was awarded the Distinguished Service Cross. T/5 Wellman's heroic actions reflect great credit upon himself, the Merrill's Marauders, and the United States Army and are in keeping with the highest traditions of the Unites States Army Rangers.

Sergeant First Class Wilton White is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military and professional career. Ranger White's Ranger career began when he was a Private and volunteered for a special unit designated the 6th Ranger Infantry Battalion. His company, Company E, was involved in the initial landings on D-2 on Dinagat Island in advance of the Philippine Invasion. On 18 October 1944, debarking from fast transport/destroyers Company E successfully eliminated any Japanese resistance destroying coast artillery guns and enemy communications on Dinagat Island, which would have impeded the invasion. Ranger White was a PFC machine gunner in the unit, which raised the first American flag on Philippine soil as part of Gen MacArthur's return to the Philippines. Later in July 1945, when he landed on Luzon, Ranger White was specifically mentioned in dispatches from both the I Corps Commander and the Sixth Army Commander and commended for his performance on hazardous missions of reconnaissance north and northeast of Baguio. The information gained resulted in the successful capture of the Baguio-Trinidad area. Both operations on Dinagat and near Baguio were classic Ranger operations, the latter being conducted in 5-6-man patrols. Upon cessation of hostilities, then SSG White served on occupation duty in Japan until the 6th Ranger Battalion was deactivated in December 1945. Ranger White returned to the Infantry in 1965 as an Instructor in the Florida Ranger Camp for a year-plus, was re-assigned to Germany and volunteered for duty in Vietnam in 1968 to 1969 where he served with distinction in the 1st BN, 18th Infantry, winning a star to the coveted Combat Infantryman's Badge. He returned to the Florida Ranger Camp for a second tour passing his extensive knowledge to fledging leaders headed to Vietnam. Although retiring in 1971, he continued his dedication and devotion to Rangers by becoming a founding member and organizer in 1973 of the US Army Ranger Association, Inc., and serving as President from 1974-1976. Ranger White's sustained dedication to the Ranger causes over a 30- year career, in and out of combat, are in keeping with highest traditions of the Ranger Creed.

CPT Al Zimmerman is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military and professional career. CPT Al Zimmerman entered the U.S. Army on 4 November 1966. During his Basic Training, at Ft. Jackson, SC. and Advanced Individual Training, at Ft. McClellan, AL. he was tested numerous times and selected to attend Officer Candidate School. During his time in Infantry Officer Candidate School, he volunteered for Aviation Training, Ranger School, and Airborne School. He attended Flight School at Ft. Wolters, Texas and Hunter Army Airfield, he graduated with qualifications in the UH-1 (Huey) and the AH-1G (Cobra.) In 1969, CPT Zimmerman was assigned to D Company, 229th Aviation Bn. Assault Helicopter Company, 1st Air Calvary Division (Air-mobile), RVN. Where he served as a Pilot, Platoon Leader and Operations Officer. Flying AH-1 G Cobras, CPT Zimmerman supported numerous LRRP and Ranger companies during severe enemy encounters in I and II Corps'. In early July 1969, CPT Zimmerman received a distress call from a LOH (Light Observation Helicopter,) that was hit and going down. The LOH went down in a small clearing and the crew was ejected. CPT Zimmerman went into a hover between the LOH and the advancing enemy and returned suppressive fire. CPT Zimmerman ordered his gunner to place the wounded LOH Crew on the Ammo Bay doors of the Cobra. CPT Zimmerman's Cobra was hit by enemy fire and he had to auto rotate into an adjacent field. Zimmerman was picked up by a UH-1 and he got on the door gun and placed suppressive fire on the enemy and began calling in air strikes on the location. CPT Zimmerman also called in the 1st Calvary's Reaction Company. This action resulted in the decimation of a large enemy unit believed to be a Battalion. CPT Zimmerman, was awarded the Silver Star for his actions. His other awards include, four awards of the Distinguished Flying Cross, for Heroism, Bronze Star, Purple Heart, and, 27 Air Medals. CPT Zimmerman lives the Ranger Creed on a daily basis.

Ms. Shelia Bowen Dudley is inducted as an honorary member to the Ranger Hall of Fame for over 28 years of outstanding service, dedication, and contributions as battalion secretary of 1st Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment. Her many contributions to the battalion include serving as a key link between family members when the battalion is deployed, community leaders, and higher headquarters. Of singular significance, Ms. Dudley undertook the leadership role to construct a 1st Battalion Memorial at Hunter Army Airfield. Over a five-year period, she raised the necessary $700,000 and supervised the construction of a beautiful memorial dedicated in 2007. Ms. Dudley's outstanding performance as secretary of 1st Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment is attested by the recognition she has received in her many awards. In 1995, she was awarded "Volunteer of the Year" by United States Special Operations Command and also the "Commander's Award for Civilian Service." In 1998, in appreciation for her outstanding service at 1st Battalion, the date of Ms. Dudley's hire, 07 July was named "Dudley Day" and is recognized annually. In her selection as "Honorary Member of the Regiment" in 1999, she became the first woman to receive this honor. In 2002, Ms. Dudley was made an Honorary Gold Star mother. Additional awards include "Commander's Award for Civilian Service" and "Civilian of the Year" Hunter Army Airfield, GA and Fort Stewart, GA, both in 2002 and 2003. In 2007, she was awarded "The Order of Saint Maurice." She was named Special Operations Command Civilian of the Year 2014 and Lifetime Achievement awardee, Charles Pimble USASOC Award 2015. Her history of going above and beyond in service to the 75th Ranger Regiment and Ranger families, along with her many significant achievements demonstrates service and commitment in the highest standing with military tradition.

Master Sergeant (Retired), Richard S. Barela served in the 75th Ranger Regiment as a career logistics NCO, with distinction from July 1974 to October 1990. He is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. MSG(R) Barela served in all three Ranger Battalions and the 75th Ranger Regiment in both peacetime and deployed as the S4 Senior Enlisted Advisor during Operation "Just Cause". Ranger Barela was awarded the Darby Leadership Award in 2019 at Fort Benning, Georgia. MSG(R) Barela continues to serve the Ranger community through a variety of non-profit organizations. Notably, he was the president of the 75th Ranger Regiment Association, where he worked tirelessly to promote the Ranger. In November 2019, he worked with various Ranger support nonprofits to organize a very successful 45th Anniversary of the 1st Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment. He is currently co-chairing the 75th Ranger Regiment Memorial Walk, a venue to be built at the Regimental Headquarters that will show the history of the modern-day rangers from WWII to the present. For exceptionally meritorious service, Ranger Barela contributions to the Nation are phenomenal and enduring. His exceptional leadership and service are in keeping with the highest traditions of the Ranger Creed, and reflect great credit upon himself, the United States Army Rangers, and the United States Army.

Chaplain (Colonel-Retired) Berry reported to the 1st Ranger Battalion in December 1990. From the start, COL(R) Berry 'Led the Way' in all training events, proving himself not only to be an excellent Chaplain, but an excellent Ranger as well. Following the helicopter crash in the Great Salt Lake in 1992, the most devastating training accident in 75th Ranger Regiment's history. COL(R) Berry provided pastoral care and counseling to his 1st Battalion Rangers. From the day of the accident, and for many years after, COL(R) Berry stood as a source of comfort for families as they dealt with their sudden and tragic loss. In the months following, he helped Ranger leaders gain their bearings as they assumed new and unexpected responsibilities. He stood as a pillar for those around him during this heart-breaking time and led the memorial ceremonies for the Battalion Commander. COL(R) Berry became the first Regimental Chaplain of the 75th Ranger Regiment in 1998. Charged with providing leadership and guidance to battalion chaplains and religious support to regimental staff, COL(R) Berry quickly ensured that ministry to the Rangers in the field met the Ranger Standard. His leadership and efforts resulted in expanded religious support for Rangers and their families both at home and while deployed. Many of the programs Rangers still enjoy today are the result of his tireless efforts, in this way, he truly set the standard. After leaving the Regimental Chaplain position, COL(R) Berry was selected to serve as the Joint Special Operations Command Chaplain. From 2012 to 2014 he constantly traveled to and from Iraq and Afghanistan, mentoring Special Operators in need. Although retired, he has never left the fight. To this day, COL(R) Berry continues to mentor and counsel Rangers and Soldiers as they confront the aftermath of combat. He is a trusted advisor who many in the Ranger community turn to first as a source of hope. Indicative of his place in Ranger history, he was invited to be the guest speaker at 1st Ranger Battalion's 45th Reunion Memorial in November of 2019. This somber event, recalling the fate of the 1st Battalion's fallen, could only be led by one man, Chaplain Steven Berry.

Master Sergeant (Retired) Alan Buford has lived the Ranger Creed through his exemplary service and leaderships in each of the three Ranger Battalions, his commitment to the Army's Special Mission Unit (SMU), and his contributions to the Ranger community post military service. MSG(R) Buford served for 20 years. He is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. Throughout his 20 year career MSG(R) Buford led the way in virtually every leadership position available to an NCO in a Rifle Company. His time training Rangers was later put to good use, training future Officers in ROTC. Ranger Buford also made combat deployments to Panama and served two tours in Bosnia and Herzegovina. When Ranger Buford wasn't leading the way in a Ranger Battalion, he was continuing to be on the cutting edge of battle in the Army's Special Mission Unit. His impact on Rangers he trained, served with and led cannot be overstated. After a very successful military career, he continued to apply the same principles and leadership in the civilian world. He was a founding member of Triple Canopy and now serves as President for Patriot Group International. In this role he has found numerous ways to give back to the Ranger community. These include mentorship, hiring Rangers and philanthropy work. For exceptionally meritorious service, Ranger Buford's contributions to the Nation are phenomenal and enduring. His exceptional leadership and service are in keeping with the highest traditions of the Ranger Creed, and reflect great credit upon himself, the United States Army Rangers, and the United States Army.

Command Sergeant Major (Retired) John Burns served more than 26 years in various Airborne, Ranger, and Light Infantry assignments throughout the United States Army. He is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. CSM(R) Burns has held every NCO leadership positions from Team Leader to Brigade Command Sergeant Major. He served with the 75th Ranger Regiment, and 3rd Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment participating in the combat parachute assault on Objective Rhino, Afghanistan in October 2001. CSM(R) Burns is a veteran of Operations "Just Cause" with the 7th Infantry Division, "Enduring Freedom I" with 3rd Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment, "Iraqi Freedom I" with the 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault), and "Enduring Freedom VII" with the 10th Mountain Division. He retired in February 2010 as the Ranger Training Brigade's Command Sergeant Major. Immediately after retiring from the military, CSM(R) Burns continues to serve the Ranger Community as the Brigade Training Specialist for the ARTB. For exceptionally meritorious service, Ranger Burns contributions to the Nation are phenomenal and enduring. His exceptional leadership and service are in keeping with the highest traditions of the Ranger Creed, and reflect great credit upon himself, the United States Army Rangers, and the United States Army.

Colonel (Retired) Arthur A. Kandarian served over 27 years in multiple Ranger leadership position with distinction. He is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. While assigned to the 82nd Airborne Division, COL(R) Kandarian participated in its combat parachute assault into Panama during Operation Just Cause, and later deployed as a member of the first ground combat unit deployed in Operation Desert Shield/Desert Storm. While assigned to 3rd Ranger Battalion, COL(R) Kandarian participated in Operation Iraqi Freedom, and was the Ranger Task Force Commander for the battle at Haditha Dam. He is a tested combat leader who in the battle for Haditha Dam, and was awarded the Silver Star for gallantry. COL(R) Kandarian served as the Chief of Staff for Special Operations Component Command/NATO Special Operations Command Afghanistan (SOFTF-A/NSOCC-A), the first two star level special operations organization which combined all special operations force in Afghanistan.
