COL® Kandarian retired from SOCOM headquarters with over 27 years for service that included combat deployments to Panama, Saudi Arabia, Haiti, Iraq and Afghanistan. In retirement, Ranger Kandarian served on the board of directors for the Wounded Warriors in Action Foundation as an advocate of the wounded veteran’s community. For exceptionally meritorious service, Ranger Kandarian’s contributions to the Nation are phenomenal and enduring. His exceptional leadership and service are in keeping with the highest traditions of the Ranger Creed, and reflect great credit upon himself, the United States Army Rangers, and the United States Army.

First Sergeant (Retired) Cummings is a battle-hardened Ranger combat veteran of both South Viet Nam and Grenada. Ranger Cummings was recruited by N Company(Ranger) 75th Infantry. Conducting Long Range Patrols for the 173d Airborne Brigade in the Central Highlands of Vietnam where he was awarded the Bronze Star for his actions against the enemy in combat. He then served as an Assistant Team Leader with B Company (Ranger) 75th Infantry, the Long Ranger Reconnaissance asset of VII Corps Germany. In 1974 Ranger Cummings served as one of the original members of the new 2nd Ranger Battalion 75th Infantry. As a Squad Leader he contributed to the new Ranger Battalion becoming certified as trained, and prepared to assume its role in the total force. After various worldwide assignments Ranger Cummings returned to 2nd Ranger Battalion as a PSG where he led his Platoon on the combat jump into Grenada during Operation Urgent Fury. Ranger Cummings Platoon was specially selected to enter the gymnasium on the Grand Ansa campus to secure American students and get them loaded on helicopters for evacuation as the remainder of the Battalion conducted the security cordon. Ranger Cummings then served as NCOIC of the Benning Phase of the US Army Ranger School where he set the example for his Ranger Instructors. Supervising the training of 11 Ranger classes, his tough, realistic, demanding standards ensured his Students were prepared to assume their role as Rangers and Leaders throughout the Army. He was then selected as a Rifle Company 1SG, for the new 10th Mountain Division where once again his leadership was instrumental in the demanding work of getting a new unit certified as trained and combat ready. Following his retirement from the US Army in 1991, Ranger Cummings continued to serve the force as a civilian with the Capabilities Development Integration Directorate at the MCoE, until his retirement in 2018. There he contributed materially to the development of the future Infantry force. Ranger Cummings' influence on the Army and the Ranger community remain evident to this day.

Sergeant Major (Retired) Michael J. Fedowitz Jr. is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for heroism, extraordinary achievement, and continued service to his country and the Special Operations Community. SGM(R) Fedowitz began his Special Operations service with A Company, 3rd Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment, where he participated in the Airborne Assault into Rio Hato, Panama during Operation Just Cause in December 1989-January 1990. He then went on to serve in positions of increasing duties and responsibilities, where he eventually served as a Platoon Sergeant, before he was assessed and selected to serve in the 75th Ranger Regiment's Regimental Reconnaissance Detachment (RRD), where he honed his skills in Reconnaissance, Surveillance, Target Acquisition, Land Navigation, Communications, Demolitions, Advanced Parachuting (HALO), and a multitude of other combat and Special Skill Sets. After serving 11 years in the 75th Ranger Regiment, SGM(R) Fedowitz then underwent the arduous selection and assessment process for the US Army Special Mission Unit (SMU), where he was selected to serve in the Army's most elite Counterterrorism Unit. SGM(R) Fedowitz spent the next 13 plus years in the SMU, where he served 8 tours of duty in Iraq, and 4 in Afghanistan. While assigned there, he conducted over 700 Direct Action Missions to include combat assaults, sniper operations, and reconnaissance missions, to include a combat HALO jump into Iraq. SGM(R) Fedowitz earned multiple awards and decorations throughout his illustrious career, including the Combat Infantryman Badge (2nd Award), Expert Infantryman Badge, Master Military Freefall Parachutist Badge (with Bronze Service Star), Master Parachutist Badge (with Bronze Service Star), Ranger Tab, Legion of Merit, Bronze Star Medal w/ V Device, Bronze Star Medal (5th Award), Purple Heart, and numerous other service and campaign medals. For exceptionally meritorious service, Ranger Fedowitz's contributions to the Nation are phenomenal and enduring. His exceptional leadership and service are in keeping with the highest traditions of the Ranger Creed, and reflect great credit upon himself, the United States Army Rangers, and the United States Army.

Command Sergeant Major (Retired) George D. Gates is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his longtime service of nearly 30 years to this country and especially for his extraordinary service in Vietnam in 1969-1970 as a Team Leader with Co P (Ranger) 75th Inf. From the time SSG Gates arrived in Vietnam as a tabbed Ranger he displayed that special talent of leadership and skills required to lead six man "hunter-killer teams" into the belly of the beast in Vietnam, the DMZ. The Team Leader position was dangerous and the responsibility for the lives they led was enormous. Gates was highly respected by all and he set an example for everyone to follow. His Team was one that everyone wanted to serve on, as he displayed a genuine affection and caring for those he led into battle. After Vietnam, Ranger Gates served in numerous leadership positions throughout the Army to include, Weapons Squad Leader 3/325th Airborne IN, Supervisor and Shift Leader 82nd Airborne Division; Senior Drill Sergeant, Ft. Jackson, SC; Rifle Platoon and Scout Platoon Sergeant CSC 3/6 IN, and First Sergeant, CSC 2/6 IN, Berlin, Germany; Senior Instructor, Georgia Southwestern College, Americus, GA; Instructor, US Army First Sergeant Course; US Army Sergeants Major Academy, Ft. Bliss, TX; Group Sergeant Major, US Army Readiness Group, St. Louis, MO; Command Sergeant Major, 6/4th Armor; Command Sergeant Major, US Army Berlin and Berlin Brigade, Berlin, Germany; Command Sergeant Major, 3rd Infantry Division, Wurzburg, Germany; and Command Sergeant Major, 1st Infantry Division, Wurzburg, Germany. Following CSM(R) Gates distinguished military career he continued to give freely of his time representing the 75th Ranger Regiment at various functions and has attended numerous events such as the Ranger Rendezvous', Camp Merrill gatherings, and most all Papa Co. Ranger reunions. For exceptionally meritorious service, Ranger Gates contributions to the Nation are phenomenal and enduring. His exceptional leadership and service are in keeping with the highest traditions of the Ranger Creed, and reflect great credit upon himself, the United States Army Rangers, and the United States Army.

Colonel (Retired) Arthur A. Kandarian served over 27 years in multiple Ranger leadership position with distinction. He is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. While assigned to the 82nd Airborne Division, COL(R) Kandarian participated in its combat parachute assault into Panama during Operation Just Cause, and later deployed as a member of the first ground combat unit deployed in Operation Desert Shield/Desert Storm. While assigned to 3rd Ranger Battalion, COL(R) Kandarian participated in Operation Iraqi Freedom, and was the Ranger Task Force Commander for the battle at Haditha Dam. He is a tested combat leader who in the battle for Haditha Dam, and was awarded the Silver Star for gallantry. COL(R) Kandarian served as the Chief of Staff for Special Operations Component Command/NATO Special Operations Command Afghanistan (SOFTF-A/NSOCC-A), the first two star level special operations organization which combined all special operations force in Afghanistan. COL Kandarian retired from SOCOM headquarters with over 27 years for service that included combat deployments to Panama, Saudi Arabia, Haiti, Iraq and Afghanistan. In retirement, Ranger Kandarian served on the board of directors for the Wounded Warriors in Action Foundation as an advocate of the wounded veteran's community. For exceptionally meritorious service, Ranger Kandarian's contributions to the Nation are phenomenal and enduring. His exceptional leadership and service are in keeping with the highest traditions of the Ranger Creed, and reflect great credit upon himself, the United States Army Rangers, and the United States Army.

Lieutenant General (Retired) Francis. H Kearney III is inducted in the Ranger Hall of Fame for distinguished and continued service to our country, and for dedicating his life and career to the values set forth in the Ranger Creed. LTG(R) Kearney graduated from Ranger School in 1977. In 1980, he arrived in Fort Lewis, WA to begin what would become 12 years of service in the 75th Ranger Regiment and 2 combat airborne assaults: OPERATION URGENT FURY and OPERATION JUST CAUSE. There, General Kearney led A Company, 2nd Battalion (Ranger), 75th Infantry into Grenada and True Blue Campus. Later, he served as the Liaison Officer for 3rd Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment in their efforts to oust the sitting dictator of Panama, Manuel Noriega, and his regime. LTG(R) Kearney commanded 3rd Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment from 1994 to 1996 before becoming the J3 and Deputy Commanding General for the Joint Special Operations Command during the invasions of Afghanistan and Iraq: OPERATION ENDURING FREEDOM and IRAQI FREEDOM. From 2005 to 2007, LTG(R) Kearney led all Special Operations Forces in the CENTCOM area of operations to include operations IRAQI FREEDOM and ENDURING FREEDOM, serving as the Commander of Special Operations Command Central Command (SOCCENT). Following his command of SOCCENT, LTG(R) Kearney became the Deputy Commander for the United States Special Operations Command where he led the manning and equipping of special operations forces and played an integral role in shaping special operations for years for the future. LTG(R) Kearney ended his military career serving as the Director for Strategic Operations, National Counter Terrorism Center. For exceptionally meritorious service, Ranger Kearney's contributions to the Nation are phenomenal and enduring. His exceptional leadership and service are in keeping with the highest traditions of the Ranger Creed, and reflect great credit upon himself, the United States Army Rangers, and the United States Army.

Colonel (Retired) Russ Kotwal, M.D., M.P.H., is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for distinguished and continued service to our country, and for dedicating his life and career to the values set forth in the Ranger Creed. COL(R) Kotwal is a legend in the 75th Ranger Regiment and is recognized for wide-ranging excellence in military medicine. He has spearheaded several life-saving initiatives within the special operations medical community, including the Pre-Hospital Trauma Registry. COL(R) Kotwal is responsible for establishing, implementing and progressing Tactical Combat Casualty Care. Through countless studies, training, and establishing new standard operating procedures, COL(R) Kotwal put Ranger Medicine at the forefront of combat medicine. COL(R) Kotwal is responsible for establishing a medical system that has saved anyone who could be saved in combat. His leadership and continual pursuit of perfection when confronted with the no fail task of saving Ranger lives has set the example for others to follow. He also established the Ranger Athlete Warrior Program, centralizing human performance training, tracking and rehabilitation. This effort synchronized rehabilitation efforts with physical training programs and streamlined wounded and injured Rangers return to duty. His operational assignments include four years with the 25th Infantry Division, nine years with the 75th Ranger Regiment, and two years with the U.S Army Special Operations Command. He has deployed to combat twelve times with the Rangers, nine times to Afghanistan and three to Iraq. He has conducted hundreds of combat ground and air missions as the senior medical provider for which he has received five Bronze Star medals, two Joint Service Commendation medals for valor, and two combat jump stars. COL Kotwal retired in 2014 after 28 years of dedicated service to our nation. In his last assignment, he served as the Deputy Command Surgeon for the U.S. Army Special Operations Command. He continues to share his vast medical knowledge as an Independent Medical Consultant. The indelible mark COL(R) Kotwal has left on Rangers, Ranger Families as well as the influence he has made through many medical initiatives, influence, and leadership have and will continue to save lives for years to come.

Technical Sergeant David B. Richardson is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for making exceptional contributions to the U.S. Army, often at the voluntary risk of his own life, in chronicling the deeds of fighting men in World War II, particularly Merrill's Marauders. As an Army journalist, TSG Richardson in 1942 established a Southwest Pacific edition of Yank, the wartime GI weekly. Dissatisfied with its reporting on the fighting in New Guinea, he volunteered to cover the combat himself, going into front-line foxholes with U.S. and Australian infantry in the jungle battles of Buna and Lae. For later articles, he replaced a waist gunner in a B-24 bomber that fended off four Zero fighters, and manned a BAR in a PT-boat sinking enemy supply vessels. Transferred to the China-Burma-India Theater in 1944, TSG Richardson immediately volunteered to join Merrill's Marauders, and became the only newsman to make their entire 500-mile trek behind Japanese lines, including four major battles. To better observe Marauder hit-and-run actions, he repeatedly exposed himself to enemy fire. His many articles and photos, reprinted in newspapers across America, were credited with gaining wide recognition for the Marauders as the spearhead of the Allied Northern Burma offensive. Later TSG Richardson continued his up-front action reporting by doubling as a bow gunner in the first American tank action in Asia, and as a nose gunner with the 490th "Bridge Busters" bomber squadron. He took part in ambush operations with an OSS-led guerrilla force, with Chinese forces in the Battle of Bhamo, and jumped with Gurkha paratroops in the capture of Rangoon. His awards included the Legion of Merit, Bronze Star and Combat Infantryman's Badge. Following retirement from a civilian journalistic career, he worked actively for more than ten years as an officer of Merrill's Marauders Association to further the Marauder/Ranger cause. For exceptionally meritorious service, Ranger Richardson's contributions to the Nation are phenomenal and enduring. His exceptional leadership and service are in keeping with the highest traditions of the Ranger Creed, and reflect great credit upon himself, the United States Army Rangers, and the United States Army.

Command Sergeant Major (Ret) Tom Siter entered the Army in 1987 as an Infantryman and culminated his military career 22 years later as the Commandant of the ARNG Warrior Training Center at Ft. Benning, GA. He continues to serve as a Department of the Army Civilian in the role of Deputy Commander, ARNG Warrior Training Center. Ranger Siter's career consisted of serving in multiple light Infantry, Airborne, and Ranger Training assignments to include leadership positions at the Squad, Platoon, Company and Battalion level in the 10th Mountain Division, 82nd Airborne Division and at the Battalion level for the 4th Ranger Training Battalion. He trained more than 14,000 Rangers while serving at 4th RTBn. Ranger Siter deployed to Afghanistan in 2003 in support of Operation Enduring Freedom. He went on to establish the ARNG Warrior Training Center to increase the number of Ranger Qualified leaders across the force. Since standing up the ARNG Warrior Training Center, CSM(R) Tom Siter trained another 15,500 Ranger students through the Ranger Training Assessment Course resulting in a Ranger School success rate up to 20% higher than the average graduation rate. Ranger Siter developed the Ranger Team Leader Initiative program which greatly changed the culture of the enlisted force in the ARNG. Additionally, under his leadership, the ARNG WTC has trained over 55,000 Soldiers in other critical skills such as Air Assault, Pathfinder, Rappel Master, Army Combative, Bradley and Abrams Training Assessment, Light Leader, and Master Fitness. He led the design and construction of a 43 acre world-class training facility and camp. Ranger Siter's service to the Ranger community spanned both Active Army and Army National Guard formations. For exceptionally meritorious service, Ranger Siter's contributions to the Nation are phenomenal and enduring. His exceptional leadership and service are in keeping with the highest traditions of the Ranger Creed, and reflect great credit upon himself, the United States Army Rangers, and the United States Army.

Colonel (Retired) Patrick L. Stevens enlisted in the Army in 1972 and began his career as a paratrooper in the 82d Airborne after graduating from Ranger School as a Private First Class. In 1974, SPC Stevens was selected to join the initial cadre to form the 1st Ranger Battalion. Although a junior NCO as Platoon Artillery Recon Sergeant and later Company FSCOORD NCO, he was deeply involved in the transition of the battalion from its formation to certification as a fully operational and worldwide deployable combat unit, especially its fire support coordination training. He was instrumental in the actual development and writing of the training objectives (tasks, conditions, and standards), which ultimately changed how the Army trained. With simultaneous membership in the Army National Guard and ROTC, he graduated from college and was commissioned in 1981. From 1982 to 1997, he progressed through professionally developing positions of increasing responsibility including Operational Detachment Alpha Commander, Special Forces Company XO, Battalion S3 and XO, primarily in the 19th Special Forces Group. In 1999, he transitioned to Title X AGR with SOCJFCOM, helping to shape the doctrine and training for Theater SOCs, then deploying to join the CJSOTF–West for the Iraq invasion. In 2004, LTC Stevens was assigned to G3 Plans, XVIII Airborne Corps, returning to Iraq during 2005-2006, where he led Multinational Corps Iraq's efforts setting conditions for successful Iraqi elections. In July 2006, he became the Chief of J3 Plans and Interagency Operations for JTF–Civil Support for consequence management. As the last-known original member of the initial cadre of the 1st Ranger Battalion to remain on active duty, Colonel Stevens retired in 2011, to be recalled for a one-year assignment with the CFSOCC in Afghanistan. As a civilian, he returned to Afghanistan for three additional tours between 2013 and 2017, focused on the establishment, training, and mentoring of Afghan Special Operations commands. Throughout his four decades of service, COL(R) Stevens personified the Abrams Charter and "always endeavored to uphold the prestige, honor, and high esprit de corps of the Rangers" and to instill that sense of duty, accountability, and warrior spirit in others. His contributions to the Ranger Brotherhood are of the highest order and an example for others to follow.

Lieutenant Colonel (Retired) Robert K. Suchke is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his exceptional leadership and embodiment of Ranger ideals. His selfless service and commitment to excellence as a Ranger was demonstrated throughout his military career as a Special Operations Officer. A charter member of Special Forces Branch, he undertook every dangerous and demanding challenge he could find. During his combat tour in Vietnam, he always moved toward the action and gallantly faced the rigors of combat while leading his Aero Rifle Platoon to rescue downed helicopter pilots and Ranger units in contact. Always seeking new challenges, he volunteered to serve with L Co 75th Inf Rangers, and did so with singular distinction. As a Ranger Instructor, he demonstrated a unique ability to impart his combat knowledge and skills to others. His inspiring leadership abilities and experience enabled him to conduct hazardous and exhausting multiple-day Ranger FTX's. Always an innovative thinker, he continually improved the Mountain Ranger Phase with innovative training aids and operational scenarios. Ranger Suchke was selected by 25th Division Commanding General, on short notice to command a Rifle Company from a different Battalion, to train and deploy that task force for a month long bilateral exercise in Australia. He did so with flawless precision garnering high praise. He was named as the 1977 Outstanding Junior Officer of the 25th Infantry Division. Ranger Suchke served in ever-increasing positions of responsibility in both Infantry and Special Forces units culminating with Command of 1st Battalion, 1st SFG(A) in Okinawa. During 26 months of command, his "A" Teams conducted numerous sensitive missions throughout the Pacific Theater in 12 different foreign nations earning accolades from both U.S. and foreign governments. In 2001, he was named Distinguished Member of the Ranger Training Brigade. Ranger Suchke thrived on leadership challenges throughout his 23 years of service. In Airborne, Infantry, Ranger, and Special Operations assignments Ranger Suchke led the way, always living up to the Ranger Creed and setting the example for others to follow.

Dr. Thomas M. Hatfield is a preeminent expert on the planning, preparation and execution of the D Day invasion. For the past four decades, he has helped to bring to life for younger generations, the historic events that occurred on 6 June 1944. He has dedicated his entire adult life in the study of our Nation's military history with emphasis on the life of James Earl Rudder and the exploits of the 2d Ranger Battalion during World War II. He is author of the 2011 acclaimed biography of MG James Earl Rudder, often described as the "Model Ranger." In writing the book, "Rudder: From Leader to Legend", Dr. Hatfield researched and wrote the story of Pointe du Hoc in authentic detail, beginning with Rudder's mission assignment on 4 January 1944, the development of the assault plan, unit and individual training, procuring and innovating equipment, the assault on 6 June, and holding the Pointe until relieved on 8 June. The book also details the battalion's exploits in Brittany and the Huertgen Forest. Dr. Hatfield has passed on his vast knowledge by presenting more than 100 lectures and power point presentations about the 2nd Ranger Battalion's assault on Pointe du Hoc to civilian and military audiences. He has inspired local efforts to erect statues of Rudder in combat gear at Tarleton State University (the first college he attended) and Brady, Texas (where he taught high school and coached football). The statues are modeled on the famous photograph taken by Ranger Major Jack Street at Pointe du Hoc on 7 June 1944. Dr. Hatfield is a Dean Emeritus and the founding Director of the Military History Institute in 2005 at the University of Texas at Austin. He is also the Co-founder of the University's Normandy Scholar Program for undergraduates to study WW II; the program includes a period of residence in Normandy. The program has been copied by other universities nationwide. The induction of Dr Tom Hatfield into the Ranger Hall of Fame serves as a lasting recognition of his lifetime commitment to the study of our Nation's military history and his profound contributions to honoring the heroic actions of Army Rangers during World War II.

Major General Jeffrey Bannister served as the 10th Mountain Division Commander and Senior Commander at Fort Drum, N.Y., for 27 months. He is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. As an Infantry Officer, MG Bannister served in various positions from Rifle Platoon Leader in the 82nd Airborne Division to Commanding General of the 10th Mountain Division. He served in the 75th Ranger Regiment as a Platoon Leader, Assistant S4, Battalion S4, Rifle Company Commander, Liaison Officer, Battalion S3, and as the Regimental Deputy Commander. His work was always characterized by a high degree of ingenuity, resolve, collaboration, unwavering commitment and certain success. He was gifted in both the planning and execution of incredibly complex Special Operations missions or working in the crisis action mode. MG Bannister is a graduate of the Infantry Officer Basic and Advance Courses, Airborne and Ranger Schools, U.S. Army Command and General Staff College, and National War College. His military awards and decorations include the Distinguished Service Medal 1 OLC, Defense Superior Service Medal 3 OLC, Legion of Merit 1 OLC, Bronze Star Medal 2 OLC, Defense Meritorious Service Medal 1 OLC, Meritorious Service Medal w/ silver OLC, Joint Service Commendation Medal, Army Commendation Medal w/ silver OLC, Joint Service Achievement 1 OLC, Army Achievement Medal 2 silver OLC, Combat Infantryman Badge, Master Parachutist Badge, Ranger Tab, Pathfinder Badge. For exceptionally meritorious service, Ranger Bannister's contributions to the Nation are phenomenal and enduring. His exceptional leadership and service are in keeping with the highest traditions of the Ranger Creed, and reflect great credit upon himself, the United States Army Rangers, and the United States Army.

Command Sergeant Major (Retired) Borja is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. Throughout his 31 years as a Ranger, boldly leading the way in assignments and missions as a leader in the 2nd and 3rd Ranger Battalions. CSM(R) Borja established exemplary standards shaping his legacy as a model for his peers. He sought every opportunity to further develop himself as a professional Soldier, accepting all challenges in the mold of the ideal Airborne Ranger. He carried the lessons he learned along the way to share with his subordinates as an inspiration to all with whom he served. A confident leader of flawless determination, resolve, and integrity. CSM(R) Borja continually demonstrated the ideals of the Ranger Creed though every assignment and mission, to include combat jumps during Operation Urgent Fury and Operation Just Cause and two deployments to Afghanistan. During Operation Just Cause, CSM(R) Borja was wounded and evacuated, earning a purple heart. He culminated his career as the Command Sergeant Major of the United States Army Space and Missile Defense Command. CSM(R) Borja has continued to support the Ranger Community as a spokesman for Rocky boots and a major supporter of the Best Ranger Competition. For exceptionally meritorious service, Ranger Borja's contributions to the Nation are phenomenal and enduring. His exceptional leadership and service are in keeping with the highest traditions of the Ranger Creed, and reflect great credit upon himself, the United States Army

Command Sergeant Major (Retired) Mark A. Collazos is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame based on a lifetime dedicated to the Ranger and Special Operations community. CSM (R) Collazos entered the United State Army on March 10th, 1986 from Lafayette, Louisiana beginning his 23 year military career. CSM(R) Collazos has served in many Light and Airborne Special Operations Units over his 23 dedicated years of service. He has served as an Ammo Bearer, Assistant Gunner, Machine Gunner, Team Leader and Weapons Squad Leader, in A-Co 3/75, Support Platoon, HHC 3/75, Team Member, Regimental Reconnaissance Detachment (RRD), Team Member, Assistant Team Leader, Special Missions Unit (SMU), Ranger Instructor and 1SG, 6th Ranger Training Battalion, and CSM 4th Ranger Training Battalion. His combat tours and duty positions include Panama (Operations Just Cause) as a HHC gun jeep TC on Rio Hato, 1989; Somalia (Operation Restore Hope) an Assault Team Member, TF Ranger, 1993; Bosnia as IFOR/SFOR Commander security detail, 1995 and 1998; Afghanistan (Operation Enduring Freedom) as the HHC 1SG, 04-05; Iraq (Operation Iraqi Freedom) as the TF 1-36IN (Mech) CSM, 06-07. CSM(R) Collazos continues to find ways to serve our great nation's military. He currently works for CACI, supporting the Squad Performance Metrics (SPM) team, Program Manager (PM) Integrated Augmented System (IVAS), Program Executive Office (PEO) Soldier, Ft. Belvoir VA. CSM(R) Collazos has clearly distinguished himself as a role model setting the standards for all Rangers to follow and his contributions undoubtedly merit inclusion among our community's finest.

Colonel (Retired) Harvey J. Cook was a key member of the 2d Ranger Battalion staff under LTC James E. Rudder during the preparation for and conduct of combat operations during World War II. As the Battalion S2 (Intelligence) Officer, he learned from his British Commando partners, German tactics, techniques, procedures, and weapons and incorporated this knowledge into unit training for the D Day invasion. He was deeply involved in preparing assault plans for the 2d and 5th Ranger Battalions on Omaha Beach and 2d Rangers specifically for Pointe du Hoc. War games, both tabletop and in the field, were integral to the preparation and Captain Cook's job was to set up the opposing force, assuring those posing as the enemy mimicked the Germans. On D Day, Captain Cook landed at H-Hour with three companies of the 2d Ranger Battalion A,B, C, and half the headquarters company attached to the 29th Division on Omaha Beach in the Dog Green sector near the Vierville Draw, where the heaviest losses occurred. Cook received the Silver Star for his courageous actions that day. His citation reads in part: "With complete disregard for his personal safety, he moved from group to group along the beach organizing an assault wave. Having completed his organization, he led his troops in a swift assault on the first ridge-line, contributing greatly towards success of the operation...". In the Brittany Campaign, Cook made a significant contribution to the success of the 2d Rangers' mission to cut off German forces at the tip of the peninsula west of Brest. The battle lasted until 9 September when the enemy commander in the area, Colonel Martin Furst, surrendered approximately 1,400 Wehrmacht soldiers to 300 Rangers. Ranger Cook set up the surrender. With information gleaned from the French resistance and a Ranger patrol, Ranger Cook entered Furst's command post alone under a white flag, and negotiated his formal surrender to Rudder. Captain Cook served with the 2d Ranger Battalion through the rest of the war, the Huertgen Forest, the Battle of the Bulge, and the concluding attacks across Germany. After Colonel Rudder departed the battalion, Captain Cook became the face of the battalion, representing stability and continuity in the headquarters. For exceptionally meritorious service, Ranger Cook contributions to the Nation are phenomenal and enduring. His exceptional leadership and service are in keeping with the highest traditions of the Ranger Creed, and reflect great credit upon himself, the United States Army Rangers, and the United States Army.

Sergeant Stephen C. Crabtree served with Company G (Ranger), 75th Infantry with distinction from April 69 - April 70. SGT Crabtree is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. Ranger Crabtree heard about some of the encounters of Ranger feats from his surrogate father, Preston Hogue, who was a member of Darby's Rangers that scaled Point du Hoc. The more Stephen learned about the Rangers, the more he wanted to be become one. He echoed the Ranger traditions by Volunteering for the United States Army, Volunteering for Vietnam and becoming a member of Company G (Ranger) 75th Infantry carrying his choice of weapon, an M-60 machine gun known affectionately to him as "Bullwinkle" for over 30 Ranger-LRRP missions. In perhaps as his greatest contribution to the Greater Ranger Community, SGT Crabtree was instrumental in the drive to put a brick in at the National Ranger Memorial for every Ranger/LRRP Killed in Action in Vietnam. He collaborated with the National Ranger Memorial, the 75th Ranger Regiment Association, and others, which resulted in nearly $100,000 for the project. Mission accomplished! He then helped raise money for bricks for those listed on the "Fallen Angels" list and members of the 1st Battalion who were killed in action or training. Volunteering is a word that he has lived up to and continues to this day. In 1990 he was instrumental in the formation of G Company Ranger Association and served as its President, Chairman of the Board of Directors, Director and Concessions Officer. In 1992 he joined the 75th Ranger Regiment Association and has served as an Operations Officer, a Unit Director, and eventually serving as President between 2005 & 2007. He sat on the Ranger Executive Board for RHOF selections. Stephen continues to serve today as a Board Member of G/75th. For exceptionally meritorious service, Ranger Crabtree's contributions to the Nation are phenomenal and enduring. His exceptional leadership and service are in keeping with the highest traditions of the Ranger Creed, and reflect great credit upon himself, the United States Army Rangers, and the United States Army.

Command Sergeant Major (Retired) Richard Davis served the Joint Special Operations Command as the Command Sergeant Major from 1996 to 1998. He is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military Career. CSM(R) Davis entered the United States Army on 17 June 1968 and was assigned to the 173rd Airborne Brigade as a Long Range Reconnaissance Patrol member in N Company, 75th Ranger Infantry. He held many NCO leadership positions within the Special Missions Unit to include Troop SGM, Squadron Operation Officer, Assessment & Selection SGM, Operational Squadron SGM and the Special Missions Unit CSM. CSM Davis has over twenty nine years of professional military experience in both Special Operations and Joint Commands. He has fifteen years of experience as a member of a premier Special Missions Unit, two years with a Joint Command and five years serving on the Command and General Staff (1993-1998).CSM(R) Davis culminated his career as the Joint Special Operations Command (JSOC). His military awards and decorations include Defense Superior Service Medal, Legion of Merit, Bronze Star, Purple Heart 1 OLC, Meritorious Service Medal, Army Commendation Medal 3 OLC, Army Good Conduct Medal 8th award, Army of Occupation Medal, National Defense Service Medal w/Bronze Service Star, Humanitarian Service Ribbon, Republic of Vietnam Campaign Medal, Joint Meritorious Unit Award 1 OLC, Valorous Unit Award, Republic of Vietnam Cross of Gallantry Unit Citation w/Palm, Republic of Vietnam Civil Action Unit Citation w/ Palm, Combat Infantryman Badge, Master Parachutist Badge, Military Free Fall Parachutist Badge, German Parachutist Badge, Malaysian Parachutist Badge, Combat Diver Badge, Drill Sergeant Identification Badge and two Overseas Service bars. For exceptionally meritorious service, Ranger Davis's contributions to the Nation are phenomenal and enduring. His exceptional leadership and service are in keeping with the highest traditions of the Ranger Creed, and reflect great credit upon himself, the United States Army Rangers, and the United States Army.

Command Sergeant Major (Retired) Carlton Dedrich is being inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for extraordinary service to the U.S. Army, the 75th Ranger Regiment and to this nation. Of the 26 years active duty CSM(R) Dedrich served, 16 and a half consecutive years were within the Ranger Community, having served with the 2nd and 3d Ranger Battalions and the Ranger Training Brigade. CSM(R) Dedrich began his service with 2nd Ranger Battalion as a Private and ended his time in the Ranger Community as a First Sergeant of two companies within the 2nd Ranger Battalion. During his time within the Ranger Regiment, he participated in two low level combat parachute operations and led Rangers into combat with distinction. Within the Regiment, he held leadership positions from rifle team leader to First Sergeant. CSM(R) Dedrich retired in 2004. In 2006, CSM(R) Dedrich was nominated and received the distinction of Distinguished Member of the 75th Ranger Regiment. After his retirement, he served as a consultant to various Army units, to include 2nd Ranger Battalion in active combat zones. Throughout his retirement, CSM(R) Dedrich continued to mentor and counsel Rangers returning from combat and assisted veterans transitioning into the civilian world. While serving as a civilian consultant for the 2nd Ranger Battalion, he was an active as a mentor and counselor to those Rangers that he was invited by the Battalion Commander and Command Sergeant Major to serve as the guest speaker for the Expert Infantryman Badge Ceremony and later the Jumpmaster Graduation Ceremony. He has never turned down the opportunity to assist active duty Rangers and Ranger veterans when it came to their health and welfare. For exceptionally meritorious service, Ranger Dedrich's contributions to the Nation are phenomenal and enduring. His exceptional leadership and service are in keeping with the highest traditions of the Ranger Creed, and reflect great credit upon himself, the United States Army Rangers, and the United States Army.

Colonel (Retired) Jack Donovan served in the Ranger Training Brigade as the Training Officer, and 5th RTB Commander with distinction. COL(R) Donovan is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his 26 years of military service. As the Brigade Operations and Training Officer COL(R) Donovan spearheaded the formal creation of the Desert Phase of Ranger School, creation of the 7th Ranger Training Battalion and the forward positioning of the phase to Dugway Proving Grounds, Utah. He also formulated the concept, training modules and organization for the Long Range Surveillance Course and the Light Leaders Course. Discovering there was no standardized procedures for conducting airborne operations in the Ranger, LRSC and Light Leaders' Courses, he initiated, crafted, staffed and implemented an Airborne Standard Operating Procedures manual for use in all phases of Ranger training. As Commander, 5th Ranger Training Battalion he designed a strategy to publicize the many contributions of the unit's Rangers in the local community and constructed an identity for the Mountain Rangers that remains in effect still today. COL(R) Donovan also took the initiative to have the Intelligence scenario for the Mountain Phase completely modernized to align with the Joint Readiness Training Center where the vast majority of students will train with their parent organizations. He then convinced the Brigade to follow suit making Ranger School phases' Intelligence scenarios common and sequential. COL(R) Donovan foresight and dedication produced other efforts that continue in today's Ranger School and his legacy remains in the mountains of North Georgia. For exceptionally meritorious service, Ranger Donovan's contributions to the Nation are phenomenal and enduring. His exceptional leadership and service are in keeping with the highest traditions of the Ranger Creed, and reflect great credit upon himself, the United States Army Rangers, and the United States Army.

Lieutenant General (Retired) Michael Ferriter is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame. LTG Ferriter served honorably in the 75th Ranger Regiment and Airborne communities for over 35 years. He served in 2d Ranger Battalion as the S-5, S-1, and Bravo Company Commander. LTG(R) Ferriter served as the 75th Ranger Regiment's S-5, where he led the staff effort to develop and commission Fort Benning's Ranger Memorial. LTG(R) Ferriter next became 3rd Ranger Battalion's Liaison Officer and S-3 Operations Officer. In October 1993, LTG(R) Ferriter deployed to Mogadishu, Somalia as part of OPERATION RESTORE HOPE. LTG(R) Ferriter then served as the Regimental S-3 Operations Officer during the preparations for deployment to Haiti. LTG(R) Ferriter commanded 3rd Ranger Battalion from July 1996 to June 1998 and took the lead in developing the 75th Ranger Combative programs with the Gracie Jiu Jitsu Academy. As 11th Infantry Regiment's Commander, LTG(R) Ferriter adapted the 75th Ranger Regiment's hand-to-hand fighting program to develop the Modern Army Combatives Program. As a general officer, LTG(R) Ferriter deployed three times to Iraq as part of OPERATION IRAQI FREEDOM, where he coordinated campaigns to counter Al Qaeda in Iraq, built Iraqi capability, and distributed counter IED technologies to the force. LTG(R) Ferriter next served as the Commanding General of Fort Benning from 2009-2010, where he approved the expansion of the 75th Ranger Regimental compound and improvements to the Ranger Training Brigade's physical facilities. After retiring from the U.S. Army in 2014, LTG(R) Ferriter dedicated his life to Veteran's assistance. He founded the Ferriter Group, a leadership development and consulting business, where he mentored countless veteran-owned businesses. Since 2018, LTG(R) Ferriter has served as the CEO of the National Veterans Memorial and Museum (NVMM), in Columbus, Ohio. For exceptionally meritorious service, Ranger Ferriter's contributions to the Nation are phenomenal and enduring. His exceptional leadership and service are in keeping with the highest traditions of the Ranger Creed, and reflect great credit upon himself, the United States Army Rangers, and the United States Army.

Sergeant Major (Retired) Clemens E. Lemke is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. SGM(R) Lemke served more than 28 years in various Ranger, and Special Operations assignments throughout his Army Career. SGM(R) Lemke had a highly successful career, especially with the Ranger community beginning with his extended combat tour in Vietnam with Company G (Ranger), 75th Infantry. Performing as Team Leader with two Ranger Teams, SGM(R) Lemke excelled in his knowledge, judgment and leadership and was asked to train and evaluate new members of the company on combat missions. While with Company G, SGM (R) Lemke was awarded a Bronze Star with "V" device and a Purple Heart. His attention to detail and leadership earned him the respect and admiration of his command staff and peers. After Vietnam, SGM (R) Lemke served with Company O (Artic Rangers), 75th Infantry in Alaska and again excelled as a leader and team member. In 1974, SGM(R) Lemke graduated from Ranger School and was the Honor Graduate of his class. He was retained at the Ranger School as an instructor assigned to 3rd Ranger Company, TSB, USAIS Ft. Benning. Following his time as a Ranger Instructor, SGM(R) Lemke was transferred to Special Forces with Detachment A, Berlin Brigade in Germany where he traveled throughout East Germany and Soviet controlled sectors to conduct sensitive collection intelligence operations. In 1979, SGM(R) Lemke was selected to conduct a highly sensitive mission in Iran and conducted multiple dangerous missions under the direction of National Command Authority, in support of a Department of Defense Special Missions unit. Often working alone, SGM (R) Lemke was again successful in his missions and was awarded the Defense Superior Service Medal and was personally commended by the President of the United States. In 1986, SGM (R) Lemke was assigned to a tier one unit, USAISA, Washington DC, (Intelligence Support Activity). In 1990, SGM (R) Lemke was operationally detailed to the CIA where he supported many different operations in various countries. Upon retirement, SGM(R) Lemke was awarded the Distinguished Service Medal. After retirement, SGM(R) Lemke worked with the CIA for approximately 20 years and between his military and CIA service, served in over 20 foreign countries. For exceptionally meritorious service, Ranger Lemke's contributions to the Nation are phenomenal and enduring. SGM(R) Lemke set the Ranger standards for others to follow.

Colonel (Retired) Clarence Matsuda is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. COL(R) Clarence Matsuda was awarded a Ranger Tab after completing Ranger School on 22 March 1962. He used his Ranger training as a Recon Platoon Leader with the 173rd ABN BDE and while serving as Executive Officer for the 82nd ABN Division Raider Detachment that included a combat deployment to the Dominican Republic. During his first tour in Vietnam, then CPT Matsuda was in command of a 9th Infantry Division Company when his unit came under withering fire from an enemy force entrenched in bunkers. Under his leadership the enemy attack was broken and Matsuda was awarded a Silver Star for his actions. CPT Matsuda was then hand-picked to command the 9th Division's Long Range Patrol Platoon and build it to a company-size unit. There his Ranger skills were invaluable when he accompanied a patrol to observe his men on a mission. The patrol made contact with the enemy and Matsuda performed rear security as the Rangers made their way to a landing zone where they were successfully extracted. He demonstrated outstanding organizational ability by selecting Ranger qualified officers as his platoon leaders and supervising his Rangers as they built a first class company area he designed at Camp bearcat. He created training for his soldiers and started a 9th Division Recondo School that was so successful, other units in Vietnam sent their long range patrols to the school for training. Retiring after more than 26 years of service to his country, Ranger Matsuda continued to lead the way by serving as an E Company unit director and attending 75th Ranger Regiment Association meetings where he nominated one of his former Rangers for president of the Association and encouraged another to run for the same office to which both were elected. COL(R) Matsuda believed Rangers lost in combat should not be forgotten and helped to design a memorial service held at E Company reunions. The Ranger Creed is sacred to COL(R) Matsuda and he has lived it in thought, word and deed. For exceptionally meritorious service, Ranger Matsuda's contributions to the Nation are phenomenal and enduring. His exceptional leadership and service are in keeping with the highest traditions of the Ranger Creed, and reflect great credit upon himself, the United States Army Rangers, and the United States Army.

Lieutenant Colonel (Retired) Mark Ponzillo is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for extraordinary achievement, and exemplary service as commander of the 25th Infantry Division's Long-Range Reconnaissance Patrol Company. In April 1966, the Commanding General 25th Infantry Division selected then Captain Ponzillo to create and command the Division's company sized reconnaissance unit. Captain Ponzillo's task was to form and train a unit that had no personnel, no equipment, and no living quarters. This provisional unit was to be formed from volunteers across the division and equipment and supplies were begged and borrowed from Third Squadron, Fourth Calvary. Captain Ponzillo set about developing a Standard Operating Procedure and combat tactics for his new unit. Many of the tactics he formulated 1966 are still are still being used by U S Special Operations units today. Captain Ponzillo commanded the LRRP Company until November of 1966. He was then reassigned to the 5th Special Forces Group Alpha, Vietnam. December of 1967 the 25th ID LRRPs were designated Company F, 50th Infantry Long Range Patrol and again later in February of 1969 the unit was designated Company F, 75th Infantry Rangers. LTC Ponzillo continued his military service until retiring in August of 1978. He served two tours in Vietnam. In addition to his tour with the 25th Infantry division, he served with the 5th Special Forces Group Alpha and MACV Studies and Observation Group in 1968-69. The unit that he was tasked to create and all the other Divisional Long Range Reconnaissance Patrol Companies performance in Vietnam laid the foundation for today's Ranger and Special Operations units. Keeping with the Ranger creed and motto, LTC(R) Ponzillo knew what was expected of him as an elite soldier, never failed his comrades and completed his mission. LTC(R) Mark Ponzillo "Leads the Way."

Colonel William Edward Powell is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for exceptionally meritorious service to the Rangers, the United States Army and the Nation. During one of his tours in the Vietnam War, he served as the Assistant Battalion Advisor to the 35th Vietnamese Ranger Battalion, where he earned a Bronze Star Medal for Valor. On 18 October 1974, just prior to the official activation of the 2d Battalion (Ranger), 75th Infantry (now known simply as the 2d Ranger Battalion), Colonel Powell served as the Battalion Executive Officer for the first two years of the battalion. During those two years, then-Major Powell helped establish and set the policies and standard operating procedures for the staff which were unique to an Airborne Ranger Battalion. His leadership and staff supervision helped the battalion as it successfully completed tactical, airborne, amphibious, arctic, jungle, desert and other environmental and skills training, and successfully complete the validation exercises which placed the unit in a world-wide deployable status. Tapping his previous experiences as a Ranger battalion executive officer and advising the Vietnamese 35th Ranger Battalion, he was selected to serve the next year as the regional infantry advisor to an Iranian Army infantry division in Kermanshah, Iran. Upon completion of his advisory duty, then-LTC Powell was assigned as the battalion commander for the 3rd Battalion, 39th Infantry, and 9th Infantry Division in Fort Lewis, Washington. He served in that capacity for the next 18 months before being selected as the commander of the 2d Battalion (Ranger), 75th Infantry. It was during this assignment that the battalion began conducting special operations training in addition to its normal environmental training. It was on one of these special operations training rehearsals on 21 September 1981 that he and 5 other Rangers, as well as a 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment pilot were killed, when the C-130 aircraft he was flying in crashed and caught fire 1,600 meters short of the runway at Indian Springs, Nevada. For exceptionally meritorious service, Ranger Powell's contributions to the Nation are phenomenal and enduring. His exceptional leadership and service are in keeping with the highest traditions of the Ranger Creed, and reflect great credit upon himself, the United States Army Rangers, and the United States Army.

Command Sergeant Major (Retired) Hugh A. Roberts is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his outstanding Ranger career, combat experience, and continued support to the Ranger community. CSM(R) Roberts has held every enlisted leadership position within the 75th Ranger Regiment from team leader to Regimental Command Sergeant Major. CSM(R) Roberts deployed in support of Operation Urgent Fury, Grenada; Operation Uphold Democracy, Haiti; Operation Safe Heaven, Panama; Operation Joint Guardian, Kosovo; Operation Enduring freedom, Afghanistan; and Operation Iraqi Freedom, Iraq. CSM(R) Roberts was considered a father like figure for his ability to coach, teach, and mentor young men in the art of Rangering and living the Ranger Creed. As the Regimental Command Sergeant Major, CSM Roberts was instrumental in standardizing the Force Modernization Section or RS8 to better equip Rangers during the War on Terror and beyond. Then Specialist Roberts participated in the daring low level, daylight, combat jump onto Point Salinas Airfield, Grenada. Follow-on missions included rescuing students from the True Blue medical campus and air assault raid on Calivigny Barracks. First Sergeant Roberts led A Company, 2nd Ranger Battalion on a no-notice deployment to Operation Uphold Democracy, Haiti. During a deployment for training to Panama, CSM Roberts was called upon to put down a Cuban refugee uprising in Operation Safe Haven. As CSM of 2nd Ranger Battalion on 9/11, CSM Roberts was on the ground when the first Rangers from the BN were deployed for Operation Enduring Freedom. During his time as the Regimental Command Sergeant Major of the 75th Ranger Regiment Operation Iraqi Freedom was initiated. Hugh Roberts was the first Ranger Command Sergeant Major to lead men in two geographically separated battlefields in modern times. CSM(R) Roberts' exceptional and selfless dedication to duty reflect great credit upon himself, the Ranger Community and the United States Army.

Lieutenant General (Retired) Robert Wagner served in Ranger and Infantry units while serving in two different campaign theaters, with 13 months of operational missions, and 38 years of service as a Ranger leader and Infantry Officer. LTG(R) Wagner is inducted into the Ranger Hall of Fame for his service and embodiment of the Ranger Creed throughout his military career. Among his assignments in the Ranger Regiment, he served as a Battalion Logistics Officer, Rifle Company Commander, Regimental S-3, and Battalion Commander. His extensive Joint, Airborne, and Special Operations experience is unparalleled through a 38 year career and were instrumental to the development of what the Special Operations Community is today. LTG(R) Wagner served with legendary distinction as a Platoon Leader, C Company, 1st Battalion, 506th Infantry, 101st Airborne Division (Airmobile) in Vietnam; Operations Officer, Advisory Team 33, United States Military Assistance Command, Vietnam; and Commander of 1st Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment, OPERATION JUST CAUSE, Panama. His last assignment was as Commanding General of the United States Army Special Operations Command, Fort Bragg, North Carolina. LTG(R) Wagner served two tours in the Pentagon on the Joint Staff, 22 years on Airborne Status, 10 years of overseas duty, and 13 years as a General Officer. For exceptionally meritorious service, Ranger Wagner's contributions to the Nation are phenomenal and enduring. His exceptional leadership and service are in keeping with the highest traditions of the Ranger Creed, and reflect great credit upon himself, the United States Army Rangers, and the United States Army.

Jonnie Melillo Clasen has been Merrill's Marauders' liaison officer for 15 years, serving as a bridge between the WW II unit and Ranger community. In 2020, the Congressional Gold Medal Act, signed into law Oct. 17, 2020, by President Donald Trump, can be traced to Jonnie's relentless 10-year-mission to obtain the award. Her media coordination resulted in global coverage and recognition for Marauders and others who brought that journey to fruition. She arranged in 2020 for a huge Merrill's Marauder memorabilia collection to be donated to Hampden-Sydney College's Wilson Center for Leadership, named after Marauder and retired LTG Sam Wilson. In 2020, she began behind-the-scenes support for the WW II Foundation's production of a Merrill's Marauder documentary to be narrated by veteran TV newsman Tom Brokaw. In 2014, Jonnie spearheaded a massive grassroots campaign giving Merrill's Marauders their first national recognition when the nation's governors signed proclamations declaring Aug. 10, 2014, the 70th anniversary of the 5307th Composite Unit Provisional disbanding, as National WW II Merrill's Marauder Day. She has been a speaker for Ft. Benning Equal Employment Office's monthly observances honoring women and Native Americans. In 2011 and 2015, she held "Rosie Socials" at the Benning Club attended by hundreds to honor the "Greatest Generation." In 2013, she arranged for ALL Ranger units and Ft. Benning's Donovan Research Library to receive complimentary copies of British author Gavin Mortimer's Merrill's Marauder book. In 2016, she began mailing informational "care packages" to ALL surviving Marauders. In 2018, she created a Merrill's Marauder capsule history DVD for the WW II Museum. In 2019, she planned the Marauders first trip to Congress. She planned Marauder Gilbert Howland's 2019 presentation at California's Pittsburgh Historical Museum commemorating his unit's 75th anniversary and Camp Stoneman.
